[[File:Eisengarn-Sessel D4.jpg|thumb|A Marcel Breuer chair, with Grete Reichardt's 'eisengarn' fabric, 1927.]]
'''''Eisengarn''''', meaning "iron yarn" in English, is a light-reflecting, strong, waxed-cotton thread. It was invented and manufactured in Germany in the mid-19th century, but is now most well known for its use in cloth woven for the tubular-steel chairs designed by [[Marcel Breuer]] while he was a teacher at the [[Bauhaus]] design school.
The yarn is also known as '''''Glanzgarn''''' ('gloss' or 'glazed' yarn). <ref>[http://www.zeitlos-berlin.de/aktuelles/eisengarn-eine-material-geschichte zeitlos-berlin.de], ''Eisengarn – Eine Material Geschichte''. Retrieved 27 November 2016</ref>
== Manufacture == Despite the name, there is no iron in ''eisengarn''. The name refers to its strength and metallic shine. It is made by soaking cotton threads in a starch and [[paraffin wax]] solution. The threads are dried and then stretched and polished by steel rollers and brushes. The end result of the process is a lustrous, tear-resistant yarn which is extremely hardwearing.<ref name=history> [http://www.wuppertal.ihk24.de/servicemarken/branchen_neu/industrie/industrie_im_bs/902782/Textilstandort_Wuppertal.html ''Industriegeschichte aus dem Bergischen land'']. Retrieved 27 November 2016</ref><ref name=video>[http://digit.wdr.de/entries/5900?index=69&q=eyJ7aH0iOlsiezE2fSIsInsxYX0iXSwie2t9IjpbInsyMn0iXSwiezF9IjpbeyJmaWVsZCI6IiJ9XX0%3D&qt=search WDR digit project. ''Eisengarnfabrikation in Barmen''.] (Video - 16 min.) Retrieved 27 November 2016</ref>
== History == [[File:Barmen (1870).jpg|thumb|Barmen (1870)]] [[File:Netz.jpg|thumb|150px|Eisengarn string bag]] The ''eisengarn'' manufacturing process was invented in the mid-19th century in a factory in [[Barmen]], now part of the city of [[Wuppertal]], east of the river [[Rhine]].<ref name="history" />
It was used as a sewing thread and for making lace, shoe laces, hat strings, ribbons, lining materials and in the cable industry.<ref name="history" />
The manufacture of the yarn gave a considerable boost to the textile industry of Barmen and the surrounding region. By 1875, the Wuppertal company Barthels & Feldhoff employed more than 300 people in eisengarn production.<ref name="history" />
In 1927 the weaver and textile designer [[Margaretha Reichardt]] (1907–1984), then a student at the Bauhaus design school, experimented and improved the quality of the thread and developed cloth and strapping material made from ''eisengarn'' for use on Marcel Breuer's tubular steel chairs, such as the [[Wassily Chair]].<ref>[https://www.bauhaus100.de/en/past/people/students/margaretha-reichardt/ Bauhaus100. ''Margaretha Reichardt'']. Retrieved 27 November 2016</ref><ref>Kreis Weimarer Land/Angermuseum Erfurt (2009). ''Margaretha Reichardt 1907-1984 Textilkunst''. [Kreis Weimarer Land/Angermuseum Erfurt]:[Erfurt], p19</ref>
Light-weight tubular steel seating was also used in aircraft seating in the 1930s and Reichardt's improved version of ''eisengarn'' was used as a covering for the seats.<ref>Stutterheim, Kerstin; Bolbrinker, Niels. (1998/2009) ''Bauhaus Modell und Mythos''. Documentary film (English and German soundtracks). Cindeoxx / Bolbrinker & Stutterheim. (available as a DVD, produced by ''AbsolutMedien GmbH'')</ref><ref>Fiedler, Jeannine and Feierabend, Peter (1999) ''Bauhaus''. Cologne, Germany: Könemann. {{ISBN|3895086002}}</ref>
A more prosaic use for the strong eisengarn thread was, and still is, for making colourful [[String bag|string shopping bags]], which were popular in the former [[East Germany]], and are now an [[Ostalgie]] item.<ref name=Tagesspiegel>[http://www.tagesspiegel.de/politik/geschichte/aus-der-mode-aus-dem-sinn/1501512.html Wiebrecht V., Skuppin, R. (2005) in Tagesspiegel. ''Aus der Mode, aus dem Sinn Das Einkaufsnetz'']. Retrieved 4 December 2016</ref> When the bag is not in use, the nature of the eisengarn yarn enables it to be compressed so that it takes up very little space.<ref>[http://www.klassik-lust.de/einkaufsnetz-nachhaltigkeit-nachhaltig-transport/ ''Klassik Lust. Eine wiederentdeckte Waren-Transportmöglichkeit''] (in German, with photo). Retrieved 27 November 2016</ref>

[[File:Caesius facial composite.jpg|thumb|Bilateral features in the face and body, such as left and right eyes, ears, lips, wrists and thighs, often show some extent of fluctuating asymmetry. Some individuals show greater asymmetry than others. ]] As a form of biological asymmetry, '''fluctuating asymmetry''' ('''FA'''), along with anti-symmetry and direction asymmetry, refers to small, random deviations away from perfect [[Symmetry in biology|bilateral symmetry]].<nowiki/><ref name="Valen1962">{{cite journal|last=Valen|first=Leigh Van|title=A Study of Fluctuating Asymmetry|journal=Evolution|date=June 1962|volume=16|issue=2|pages=125–142|jstor=2406192|doi=10.2307/2406192}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Fluctuating Asymmetry|last=Tomkins|first=J. L.|last2=Kotiaho|first2=J. S.|publisher=Macmillan Publishers Ltd.|year=2001|isbn=|location=London|pages=1–5}}</ref> This deviation from perfection is thought to reflect the genetic and environmental pressures experienced throughout development, with greater pressures resulting in higher levels of asymmetry.<ref name="Valen1962" /> Examples of FA in the human body include unequal sizes (asymmetry) of bilateral features in the face and body, such as left and right eyes, ears, wrists, [[breast]]s, [[testicle]]s, and thighs.
Research has exposed multiple factors that are associated with FA. As measuring FA can indicate developmental stability, it can also suggest the genetic fitness of an individual. This can further have an effect on mate attraction and sexual selection, as less asymmetry reflects greater developmental stability and subsequent fitness.<ref name=":1" /> Human [[Health|physical health]] is also associated with FA. For example, young men with greater FA report more medical conditions than those with lower levels of FA.<ref name="Fluctuating asymmetry and physical health among young adults" /> Multiple other factors can be linked to FA, such as intelligence<ref name=":1" /> and personality traits.<ref name=":2" />
== Measurement == Fluctuating asymmetry (FA) can be measured by the equation: Mean FA = mean absolute value of left sides - mean absolute value of right sides.
The closer the mean value is to zero, the lower the levels of FA, indicating more symmetrical features. By taking many measurements of multiple traits per individual, this increases the accuracy in determining that individual's developmental stability. However, these traits must be chosen carefully, as different traits are affected by different selection pressures.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Patrice|first=D.|last2=Hingle|first2=A.|last3=Fowler|first3=K.|last4=Pomiankowski|first4=A.|date=1999|title=Measurement bias and fluctuating asymmetry estimates.|url=|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=57|issue=1|pages=251–253|doi=10.1006/anbe.1998.0977|pmid=}}</ref>
This equation can further be used to study the distribution of asymmetries at population levels, to distinguish between traits that show FA, directional asymmetry, and anti-symmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Swaddle|first=J. P.|date=2003|title=Fluctuating asymmetry, animal behaviour, and evolution.|url=|journal=Advances in the study of behaviour.|doi=|pmid=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Palmer|first=R.|last2=Strobeck|first2=C.|date=1992|title=Fluctuating asymmetry as a measure of developmental stability: Implications of non-normal distributions and power of statistical tests.|url=|journal=Acta Zoologica Fennica|pages=57–72|doi=|pmid=}}</ref> The distribution of FA around a mean point of zero suggests that FA is not an adaptive trait, where symmetry is ideal. Directional asymmetry of traits can be distinguished by showing significantly biased measurements towards traits being larger on either the left or right sides, for example, human [[testicle]]s (where the right is more commonly larger), or handedness (85% are right handed, 15% are left handed). Anti-symmetry can be distinguished by the bimodal distributions, due to some adaptive functions.
== Causes == Fluctuating asymmetry (FA) is often considered to be the product of [[Developmental biology|developmental]] stress and instability, caused by both genetic and environmental stressors. The notion that FA is a result of genetic and environmental factors is supported by [[C. H. Waddington|Waddington's]] notion of [[Canalisation (genetics)|canalisation]], which implies that FA is a measure of the [[genome|genome's]] ability to successfully buffer development to achieve a normal [[phenotype]] under imperfect environmental conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=WADDINGTON|first=C. H.|title=Canalization of Development and the Inheritance of Acquired Characters|url=http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/150563a0|journal=Nature|volume=150|issue=3811|pages=563–565|doi=10.1038/150563a0}}</ref> Various factors causing developmental instability and FA include [[infection]]s, [[mutation]]s, and [[toxin]]s.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The evolutionary biology of human female sexuality|last=Thornhill, Gangestad|first=Randy, Steven W.|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2008|isbn=0195340981|location=Oxford, England|pages=162–168}}</ref>
=== Genetic factors === Research on [[twin]]s suggests that there are genetic influences on FA,<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Johnson|first=Wendy|last2=Segal|first2=Nancy L.|last3=Bouchard Jr.|first3=Thomas J.|date=2008-05-01|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and general intelligence: No genetic or phenotypic association|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160289607000967|journal=Intelligence|volume=36|issue=3|pages=279–288|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2007.07.001}}</ref> and increased levels of mutations and perturbations is also linked to greater asymmetry.<ref name=":1" />
FA may also result from a lack of genetic immunity to diseases, as those with higher FA show less effective immune responses.<ref name=":3" /> This is further supported by evidence showing an association between FA and the number of respiratory infections experienced by an individual, such that those with higher levels of FA experience more infections.<ref name=":1" /> Increased prevalence of parasites and diseases in an organism is also seen more in individuals with greater levels of FA.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Fink|first=Bernhard|last2=Neave|first2=Nick|last3=Manning|first3=John T.|last4=Grammer|first4=Karl|date=2006-08-01|title=Facial symmetry and judgements of attractiveness, health and personality|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886906000973|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=41|issue=3|pages=491–499|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2006.01.017}}</ref> However, the research in this field is predominantly correlational, so caution must be taken when inferring causation. For example, rather than a lack of immunity causing FA, FA may weaken the immune responses of an organism, or there may be another factor involved.
There is some speculation that [[inbreeding]] contributes towards FA. One study on young Turkish males demonstrated that, although inbred individuals show more asymmetry in observed bilateral traits, the differences were not significant.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Özener|first=Bariş|date=2010-07-01|title=Effect of inbreeding depression on growth and fluctuating asymmetry in Turkish young males|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajhb.21046/abstract|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|language=en|volume=22|issue=4|pages=557–562|doi=10.1002/ajhb.21046|issn=1520-6300}}</ref> Furthermore, ant colonies created by an inbreeding queen do not show significantly higher FA than those produced by a non-inbreeding queen.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Keller|first=Laurent|last2=Passera|first2=Luc|date=1993-09-01|title=Incest avoidance, fluctuating asymmetry, and the consequences of inbreeding in Iridomyrmex humilis, an ant with multiple queen colonies|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00216600|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|language=en|volume=33|issue=3|pages=191–199|doi=10.1007/BF00216600|issn=0340-5443}}</ref>
=== Environmental factors === Multiple sources provide information on environmental factors that are correlated with FA. A meta-analysis of related studies suggests that FA is an appropriate marker of environmental stress during development.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Beasley|first=De Anna E.|last2=Bonisoli-Alquati|first2=Andrea|last3=Mousseau|first3=Timothy A.|date=2013-07-01|title=The use of fluctuating asymmetry as a measure of environmentally induced developmental instability: A meta-analysis|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1470160X13000988|journal=Ecological Indicators|volume=30|pages=218–226|doi=10.1016/j.ecolind.2013.02.024}}</ref>
Some evidence suggests that [[poverty]] and [[Malnutrition|lack of food]] during development may contribute to greater levels of FA.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ozener|first=Bariş|date=2011-12-01|title=Does urban poverty increase body fluctuating asymmetry?|journal=Collegium Antropologicum|volume=35|issue=4|pages=1001–1005|issn=0350-6134|pmid=22397230}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mallard|first=Samantha T.|last2=Barnard|first2=C. J.|date=2004-02-01|title=Food stress, fluctuating asymmetry and reproductive performance in the gryllid crickets Gryllus bimaculatus and Gryllodes sigillatus|url=http://booksandjournals.brillonline.com/content/journals/10.1163/156853904322890825|journal=Behaviour|volume=141|issue=2|pages=219–232|doi=10.1163/156853904322890825|issn=1568-539X}}</ref> [[Infection|Infectious diseases]] can also lead to FA, as studies have repeatedly shown that those with higher FA report more infections.<ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Møller|first=Anders Pape|date=2006-03-01|title=A review of developmental instability, parasitism and disease: Infection, genetics and evolution|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S156713480500064X|journal=Infection, Genetics and Evolution|volume=6|issue=2|pages=133–140|doi=10.1016/j.meegid.2005.03.005}}</ref> Alternatively, this association between levels of FA and infections may be due to a lack of immunity to diseases, as mentioned earlier (see 'Genetic factors'). Fluctuating asymmetry in human males is also seen to positively correlate with levels of [[oxidative stress]]. This process occurs when an organism creates excess reactive oxygen species (ROS) compared to ROS-neutralising antioxidants.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gangestad|first=Steven W.|last2=Merriman|first2=Leslie A.|last3=Emery Thompson|first3=Melissa|date=2010-12-01|title=Men’s oxidative stress, fluctuating asymmetry and physical attractiveness|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347210003416|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=80|issue=6|pages=1005–1013|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2010.09.003}}</ref> Oxidative stress may mediate the association seen between high FA and infection amounts during development.<ref name=":1" />
Toxins and poisons are considered to increase FA. [[Morning sickness|Pregnancy sickness]] is argued to be an [[adaptation]] for avoiding toxins during [[Prenatal development|foetal development]]. Research has reported that when a mother has no sickness or a sickness that extends beyond week 12 of gestation, the offspring shows higher FA (as demonstrated by measuring thigh circumferences). This suggests that when a mother fails to expel environmental toxins, this creates stress and developmental instability for the foetus, later leading to increased asymmetry in that individual.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Singh|first=Devendra|last2=Rosen|first2=Valerie C.|title=Effects of maternal body morphology, morning sickness, gestational diabetes and hypertension on fluctuating asymmetry in young women|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S1090513801000824|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|volume=22|issue=6|pages=373–384|doi=10.1016/s1090-5138(01)00082-4}}</ref> Greater exposure to [[pollution]] may also be a fundamental cause of FA. Research on skull characteristics of [[Grey seal|Baltic grey seals]] (''Halichoerus grypus'') demonstrated that those born after 1960 (marking an increase in environmental pollution) had increased levels of asymmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Zakharov|first=Vladmir M.|last2=Yablokov|first2=Alexay V.|date=1990-01-01|title=Skull Asymmetry in the Baltic Grey Seal: Effects of Environmental Pollution|journal=Ambio|volume=19|issue=5|pages=266–269|jstor=4313708}}</ref> Also, [[Greater white-toothed shrew|shrews]] (''Crocidura russula)'' from more polluted areas show higher levels of asymmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sánchez-Chardi|first=Alejandro|last2=García-Pando|first2=Marián|last3=López-Fuster|first3=María José|date=2013-10-01|title=Chronic exposure to environmental stressors induces fluctuating asymmetry in shrews inhabiting protected Mediterranean sites|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0045653513008023|journal=Chemosphere|volume=93|issue=6|pages=916–923|doi=10.1016/j.chemosphere.2013.05.056|pmid=23800592}}</ref> Radioactive contamination may also increase FA levels, as [[Yellow-necked mouse|mice]] (''Apodemus flavicollis'') living closer to the failed [[Chernobyl disaster|Chernobyl reactor]] show greater asymmetry.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Oleksyk|first=Taras K|last2=Novak|first2=James M|last3=Purdue|first3=James R|last4=Gashchak|first4=Sergiy P|last5=Smith|first5=Michael H|date=2004-01-01|title=High levels of fluctuating asymmetry in populations of Apodemus flavicollis from the most contaminated areas in Chornobyl|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0265931X03002224|journal=Journal of Environmental Radioactivity|volume=73|issue=1|pages=1–20|doi=10.1016/j.jenvrad.2003.07.001}}</ref>
== Developmental stability == Developmental stability is achieved when an organism is able to withstand genetic and environmental stress, to display the bilaterally symmetrical traits determined by its developmentally programmed phenotype.<ref name="Valen1962" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Markow|first=Therese Ann|date=1995-01-01|title=Evolutionary Ecology and Developmental Instability|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1146/annurev.en.40.010195.000541|journal=Annual Review of Entomology|volume=40|issue=1|pages=105–120|doi=10.1146/annurev.en.40.010195.000541|pmid=<!--none-->}}</ref> To measure an individual's developmental stability, the FA measurements of 10 traits are added together, including ear width, elbows, ankles, wrists, feet, length of ears and fingers. This is achieved by: (L - R)trait 1 + (L - R)trait 2 + ......(L - R)trait 10. This provides a good overall measure of body FA, as every individual has some features that are not perfectly symmetrical.
Common environmental pressures leading to lower developmental stability include exposure to toxins, poison and infectious diseases, low food quality and malnutrition. Genetic pressures include spontaneous new mutations, and "bad genes" (genes that once had adaptive functions, but are being removed through evolutionary selection). A large fluctuating asymmetry (FA) and a low developmental stability suggests that an organism is unable to develop according to the ideal state of bilateral symmetry. The energy required for bilateral symmetry development is extremely high, making perfect bilateral symmetry rare. Energy is invested into survival in spite of the genetic and environmental pressures, before making bilaterally symmetrical traits. Research has also revealed links between FA and depression, genetic or environmental stress and measures of mate quality for sexual selection.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Graham | first1 = J. H. | year = 1992 | title = Genomic coadaption and development stability in hybrid zones | url = | journal = Acta Zool. Fenn. | volume = 191 | issue = | pages = 121–132 }}</ref><ref>Graham, J. H., D. C. Freeman and J. M. Emlen. 1993. Developmental stability: A sensitive indicator of populations under stress, pp. 1366158. /)I W. G. Landis, J. S. Hughes and M. A. Lewis (Eds.), Environmental Toxicology and Risk Assessment. American Society for Testing and Materials, Philadelphia, PA.</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Tomkins | first1 = J. L. | last2 = Simmons | first2 = L. W. | year = 1995 | title = Patterns of fluctuating asymmetry in earwig forceps: No evidence for reliable signalling | url = | journal = Proc. Roy. Soc. Lond. B | volume = 259 | issue = | pages = 89–96 | doi=10.1098/rspb.1995.0014}}</ref><ref>Moller, A. P. 1994. Sexual Selection and the Barn Swallow. Oxford University Press. Oxford.</ref>
==Health==
===Susceptibility to diseases===
Research has linked higher levels of fluctuating asymmetry (FA) to poorer outcomes in some domains of physical health in humans. For example, one study found that individuals with higher levels of FA report a higher number of medical conditions than those with lower levels of FA. However, they did not experience worse outcomes in areas such as systolic blood pressure or cholesterol levels.<ref name="Fluctuating asymmetry and physical health among young adults">{{cite journal|last1=Milne|first1=Barry J|last2=Belsky|first2=Jay|last3=Poulton|first3=Richie|last4=Thomson|first4=W. ===Health-risk behaviours===
It has been suggested that individuals with lower levels of FA may engage in more biologically costly behaviours such as recreational drug use<ref name="FA and recreational drug use">{{cite journal|last1=Borkowska|first1=Barbara|last2=Powlowski|first2=Boguslaw|title=Recreational drug use and fluctuating asymmetry: Testing the handicap principle|journal=Evolutionary Psychology|date=2014|volume=12|issue=4|pages=769–782|doi=10.1177/147470491401200407|url=http://evp.sagepub.com/content/12/4/147470491401200407.full.pdf|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref> and risky body modifications such as piercings and tattoos.<ref name="FA and body modifications">{{cite journal|last1=Koziel|first1=Slawomir|last2=Kretschmer|first2=Weronika|last3=Pawlowski|first3=Boguslaw|title=Tattoos and piercings as signals of biological quality|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=May 2010|volume=31|issue=3|pages=187–192|doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2009.09.009|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513809001081/1-s2.0-S1090513809001081-main.pdf?_tid=b5486258-d8b9-11e5-8049-00000aacb360&acdnat=1456072962_ccd483dbe287c8df40e2f09b89d3faef|accessdate=21 February 2016}}</ref> These ideas have been proposed in the context of Zahavi's handicap principle, which argues that highly costly behaviours or traits serve as signals of an organism's genetic quality.<ref name="Handicap principle">{{cite book|last1=Zahavi|first1=Amotz|title=The handicap principle: a missing piece of Darwin's puzzle|date=1997|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Oxford|isbn=0-19-510035-2}}</ref> The relationship between FA and behaviours with high health risks has received mixed support. Individuals with body piercings and tattoos (which increase risk of blood-borne infections) have been shown to have lower levels of FA,<ref name="FA and body modifications" /> but individuals with lower FA do not engage in any more recreational drug use than those with higher FA levels.<ref name="FA and recreational drug use" />
===Mental health in humans===
Higher levels of FA have been linked to higher levels of some mental health difficulties. For instance, it has been shown that, among university students, higher FA is associated with higher levels of [[schizotypy]].<ref name="FA and schizotypy">{{cite journal|last1=Thoma|first1=Robert J|last2=Gangestad|first2=Steven W|last3=Euler|first3=Matthew J|last4=Lysne|first4=Per A|last5=Monnig|first5=Mollie|last6=Yeo|first6=Ronald A|title=Developmental instability and markers of schizotypy in university students|journal=Evolutionary Psychology|date=2008|volume=6|issue=4|pages=586–594|doi=10.1177/147470490800600405|url=http://evp.sagepub.com/content/6/4/147470490800600405.full.pdf+html|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> [[Depression (mood)|Depression]] scores have been found to be higher in men, but not women, with higher levels of FA.<ref name="FA and depression study">{{cite journal|last1=Martin|first1=S. M.|last2=Manning|first2=J. T.|last3=Dowrick|first3=C. F.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry, relative digit length, and depression in men|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=May 1999|volume=20|issue=3|pages=203–214|doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(99)00006-9|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513899000069/1-s2.0-S1090513899000069-main.pdf?_tid=1e380100-d735-11e5-857b-00000aacb35d&acdnat=1455906064_9b57779e04f695f26b30b1632711a33d|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> One study by Shackelford and Larsen found that men and women with higher facial asymmetry reported more physiological complaints than those with lower facial asymmetry, and that both men and women with higher asymmetry experienced higher levels of psychological distress overall. For example, men with higher facial asymmetry experienced higher levels of depression compared to men with lower facial asymmetry.<ref name="FA and psychological, emotional and physiological distress">{{cite journal|last1=Shackelford|first1=Todd K|last2=Larsen|first2=Randy J|title=Facial asymmetry as an indicator of psychological, emotional and physiological distress|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|date=February 1997|volume=72|issue=2|pages=456–466|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.72.2.456|url=http://media.proquest.com/media/csa/psycarticles-set-c/PSP/72/psp_72_2_456.pdf.pdf?hl=&cit%3Aauth=Shackelford%2C+Todd+K.%3BLarsen%2C+Randy+J.&cit%3Atitle=Facial+asymmetry+as+an+indicator+of+psychological%2C+emotional%2C+and+physiological+distress.&cit%3Apub=Journal+of+Personality+and+Social+Psychology&cit%3Avol=72&cit%3Aiss=2&cit%3Apg=456&cit%3Adate=Feb+1997&ic=true&cit%3Aprod=PsycINFO&_%3D%3D&_s=AN3NIMckqXWhnjrcLomnr%2FMiehE%3D|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> Fluctuating asymmetry has also been studied in relation to [[psychopathy]]. One study looking at offenders and non-offenders found that, although offenders had higher levels of FA overall, psychopathic offenders had lower levels of FA compared to offenders who did not meet the criteria for psychopathy. Additionally, offenders with the highest levels of psychopathy were found to have similar levels of FA to non-offenders.<ref name="FA and psychopathy">{{cite journal|last1=Lalumière|first1=Martin L.|last2=Harris|first2=Grant T.|last3=Rice|first3=Marnie E.|title=Psychopathy and developmental instability|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=March 2001|volume=22|issue=2|pages=75–92|doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(00)00064-7|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513800000647/1-s2.0-S1090513800000647-main.pdf?_tid=cc96d546-f279-11e5-9394-00000aacb35d&acdnat=1458904244_aa8c96f24a6263a180b065a92c01d859|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref>
===Other health issues in humans===
Research has also linked FA to conditions such as lower back pain, although the evidence is mixed. While one study found no notable link between pelvic asymmetry and lower back pain,<ref name="FA not linked to lower back pain">{{cite journal|last1=Levangie|first1=P. K.|title=The association between static pelvic asymmetry and low back pain|journal=Spine|date=June 1999|volume=24|issue=12|pages=1234–1242|doi=10.1097/00007632-199906150-00011}}</ref> other studies have found pelvic asymmetry (as well as FA in other traits not directly related to pelvic function) to be higher in patients experiencing lower back pain,<ref name="FA and low back pain">{{cite journal|last1=Al-Eisa|first1=Einas|last2=Egan|first2=David|last3=Wassersug|first3=Richard|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and low back pain|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=January 2004|volume=25|issue=1|pages=31–37|doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(03)00081-3|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513803000813/1-s2.0-S1090513803000813-main.pdf?_tid=3344caec-f675-11e5-ad64-00000aab0f6b&acdnat=1459342073_58aa742594c6ef6ef33ff03833646e59|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> and higher levels of FA have also been linked to congenital spinal problems.<ref name="FA and congenital spinal problems">{{cite journal|last1=Goldberg|first1=Caroline J.|last2=Fogarty|first2=Esmond E.|last3=Moore|first3=David P.|last4=Dowling|first4=Frank E.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and vertebral malformation. A study of palmar dermatoglyphics in congenital spinal deformities.|journal=Spine|date=April 1997|volume=22|issue=7|pages=775–779|doi=10.1097/00007632-199704010-00014}}</ref> Studies have also shown increased levels of FA of ear length in individuals with cleft lip and/or non-syndromic [[Cleft lip and palate|cleft palate syndrome]].<ref name="FA and CL/CP">{{cite journal|last1=Neiswanger|first1=Katherine|last2=Cooper|first2=Margaret E.|last3=Liu|first3=You-e|last4=Hu|first4=Dan-ning|last5=Melnick|first5=Michael|last6=Weinberg|first6=Seth M.|last7=Marazita|first7=Mary L.|title=Bilateral Asymmetry in Chinese Families With Cleft Lip With or Without Cleft Palate|journal=The Cleft Palate-Craniofacial Journal|date=March 2005|volume=42|issue=2|pages=192–196|doi=10.1597/03-032.1|url=http://www.cpcjournal.org/doi/pdf/10.1597/03-032.1|accessdate=2 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="FA and cleft palate syndrome">{{cite journal|last1=Lu|first1=Da-wei|last2=Shi|first2=Bing|last3=Chen|first3=Huai-qing|last4=He|first4=Xing|last5=Liao|first5=Li-shu|last6=Zheng|first6=Qian|title=A Comparative Study of Fluctuating Asymmetry in Chinese Families With Nonsyndromic Cleft Palate|journal=The Cleft Palate-Craniofacial Journal|date=March 2010|volume=47|issue=2|pages=182–188|doi=10.1597/08-197.1|url=http://www.cpcjournal.org/doi/pdf/10.1597/08-197.1|accessdate=2 April 2016}}</ref><ref name="FA and cleft palate in colombian, phillipine and ethiopian families">{{cite journal|last1=Otero|first1=Liliana|last2=Bermudez|first2=Luis|last3=Lizarraga|first3=Karina|last4=Tangco|first4=Irene|last5=Gannaban|first5=Rocelyn|last6=Meles|first6=Daniel|title=A Comparative Study of Facial Asymmetry in Philippine, Colombian, and Ethiopian Families with Nonsyndromic Cleft Lip Palate|journal=Plastic Surgery International|date=2012|volume=2012|pages=1–6|doi=10.1155/2012/580769}}<!--|accessdate=2 April 2016--></ref>
===Physical fitness in humans===
In addition to general health and susceptibility to disease, research has also studied the link between FA and physical fitness. Research has found that lower levels of lower-body FA is associated with faster running speeds in Jamaican sprinters,<ref name="FA and running speed">{{cite journal|last1=Trivers|first1=Robert|last2=Fink|first2=Bernhard|last3=Russell|first3=Mark|last4=McCarty|first4=Kristofor|last5=James|first5=Bruce|last6=Palestis|first6=Brian G.|last7=d'Ettorre|first7=Patrizia|title=Lower Body Symmetry and Running Performance in Elite Jamaican Track and Field Athletes|journal=PLoS ONE|date=17 November 2014|volume=9|issue=11|pages=e113106|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0113106|url=http://media.proquest.com/media/pq/classic/doc/3499267961/fmt/pi/rep/NONE?hl=&cit%3Aauth=Trivers%2C+Robert%3BFink%2C+Bernhard%3BRussell%2C+Mark%3BMcCarty%2C+Kristofor%3BJames%2C+Bruce%3BPalestis%2C+Brian+G&cit%3Atitle=Lower+Body+Symmetry+and+Running+Performance+in+Elite+Jamaican+Track+and+Field+Athletes%3A+e113106&cit%3Apub=PLoS+One&cit%3Avol=9&cit%3Aiss=11&cit%3Apg=n%2Fa&cit%3Adate=Nov+2014&ic=true&cit%3Aprod=PsycINFO&_%3D%3D&_s=38svdV9ZZ93uNEqkkDeyoQeaSg8%3D|accessdate=2 April 2016|pmid=25401732|pmc=4234648}}</ref> and individuals with greater body asymmetry have been shown to move more asymmetrically while running, although do not experience higher metabolic costs than more symmetrical individuals.<ref name="FA and running symmetry">{{cite journal|last1=Seminati|first1=Elena|last2=Nardello|first2=Francesca|last3=Zamparo|first3=Paola|last4=Ardigò|first4=Luca P.|last5=Faccioli|first5=Niccolò|last6=Minetti|first6=Alberto E.|last7=Carrier|first7=David|title=Anatomically Asymmetrical Runners Move More Asymmetrically at the Same Metabolic Cost|journal=PLoS ONE|date=24 September 2013|volume=8|issue=9|pages=e74134|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0074134|url=http://media.proquest.com/media/pq/classic/doc/3080825361/fmt/pi/rep/NONE?hl=&cit%3Aauth=Seminati%2C+Elena%3BNardello%2C+Francesca%3BZamparo%2C+Paola%3BArdig%C3%B2%2C+Luca+P%3BFaccioli%2C+Niccol%C3%B2%3BMinetti%2C+Alberto+E&cit%3Atitle=Anatomically+Asymmetrical+Runners+Move+More+Asymmetrically+at+the+Same+Metabolic+Cost%3A+e74134&cit%3Apub=PLoS+One&cit%3Avol=8&cit%3Aiss=9&cit%3Apg=n%2Fa&cit%3Adate=Sep+2013&ic=true&cit%3Aprod=PsycINFO&_%3D&_s=%2FDYsQV8GJX%2F0DNcZPSrUJsp51Rs%3D|accessdate=2 April 2016|pmid=24086316|pmc=3782489}}</ref> It has also been shown that children with lower levels of lower-body FA have faster sprinting speeds and are more willing to sprint when followed up in adulthood.<ref name="FA, speed and willingness to sprint">{{cite journal|last1=Trivers|first1=Robert|last2=Palestis|first2=Brian G.|last3=Manning|first3=John T.|last4=Fink|first4=Bernhard|title=The Symmetry of Children’s Knees Is Linked to Their Adult Sprinting Speed and Their Willingness to Sprint in a Long-Term Jamaican Study|journal=PLoS ONE|date=19 August 2013|volume=8|issue=8|pages=e72244|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0072244|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0072244|accessdate=2 April 2016}}</ref>
===Health in non-human populations===
The relationship between FA, health and susceptibility to disease has also been studied in non-human animals. For example, studies have found that higher levels of facial asymmetry are associated with poorer overall health in female rhesus macaques (''Macaca mulatta''),<ref name="FA and health in female macaques">{{cite journal|last1=Little|first1=Anthony C.|last2=Paukner|first2=Annika|last3=Woodward|first3=Ruth A.|last4=Suomi|first4=Stephen J.|title=Facial asymmetry is negatively related to condition in female macaque monkeys|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|date=21 July 2012|volume=66|issue=9|pages=1311–1318|doi=10.1007/s00265-012-1386-4|url=http://media.proquest.com/media/pq/classic/doc/2748861961/fmt/pi/rep/NONE?hl=&cit%3Aauth=Little%2C+Anthony+C%3BPaukner%2C+Annika%3BWoodward%2C+Ruth+A%3BSuomi%2C+Stephen+J&cit%3Atitle=Facial+asymmetry+is+negatively+related+to+condition+in+female+macaque+monkeys&cit%3Apub=Behavioral+Ecology+and+Sociobiology&cit%3Avol=66&cit%3Aiss=9&cit%3Apg=1311&cit%3Adate=Sep+2012&ic=true&cit%3Aprod=PsycINFO&_%3D%3D&_s=MAMCvAoYUz1EfxAJfVCgE6akFXY%3D|accessdate=30 March 2016|pmc=3649767}}</ref> and that higher FA is also linked to more health issues in chimpanzees (''Pan troglodytes'').<ref name="FA and health in chimpanzees">{{cite journal|last1=Sefcek|first1=Jon A.|last2=King|first2=James E.|title=Chimpanzee facial symmetry: A biometric measure of chimpanzee health.|journal=American Journal of Primatology|date=2007|volume=69|issue=11|pages=1257–1263|doi=10.1002/ajp.20426|pmid=17387675}}</ref>
The link between FA and health has also been investigated in non-primates. In three gazelle species (''Gazella cuvieri; Gazella dama; Gazella dorcas''), for instance, FA has been linked to a range of blood parameters associated with health in mammals, although the specific relevance of these blood parameters for these gazelle species was not examined.<ref name="FA and blood parameters in gazelles">{{cite journal|last1=Cuervo|first1=José Javier|last2=Dhaoui|first2=Mohamed|last3=Espeso|first3=Gerardo|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and blood parameters in three endangered gazelle species|journal=Mammalian Biology|date=July 2011|volume=76|issue=4|pages=498–505|doi=10.1016/j.mambio.2011.01.007|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1616504711000085/1-s2.0-S1616504711000085-main.pdf?_tid=fd3356e4-f67e-11e5-a5a0-00000aab0f26&acdnat=1459346278_36c5ab2b6d055a31818b2842befb9983|accessdate=30 March 2016}}</ref> It has also been found that, among Iberian red deer (''Cervus elaphus hispanicus''), higher FA was slightly negatively related to both antler size and overall body mass (traits thought to indicate overall condition). Antlers more involved in fighting were found to be more symmetrical than those not involved, and antler asymmetry at reproductive age was lower than in development or at post-reproductive age.<ref name="FA and antler size/body mass">{{cite journal|last1=Mateos|first1=Concha|last2=Alarcos|first2=Susana|last3=Carranza|first3=Juan|last4=Sánchez-Prieto|first4=Cristina B.|last5=Valencia|first5=Juliana|title=Fluctuating asymmetry of red deer antlers negatively relates to individual condition and proximity to prime age|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=May 2008|volume=75|issue=5|pages=1629–1640|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2007.10.016}}<!--|accessdate=30 March 2016--></ref>
FA and health outcomes have been examined within insect populations. For instance, it has been found that Mediterranean field crickets (''Gryllus bimaculatus'') with higher levels of FA in three hind-limb traits have lower encapsulation rates, but do not differ from low-FA crickets in lytic activity (both are measures of immunocompetence).<ref name="FA and immune function in field crickets">{{cite journal|last1=Rantala|first1=Markus J.|last2=Ahtiainen|first2=Jari J.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and immune function in a field cricket.|journal=Oikos|date=December 2004|volume=107|issue=3|pages=479–484|doi=10.1111/j.0030-1299.2004.12776.x}}<!--|accessdate=30 March 2016--></ref> While research on the relationship between FA and longevity is sparse in humans, some studies using non-human populations have suggested an association between the symmetry of an organism and its lifespan. For instance, it has been found that flies whose wing veins showed more bilateral symmetry live longer than less symmetrical flies. This difference was greatest for male flies.<ref name="Flies' symmetry and longevity">{{cite journal|last1=Harshman|first1=Lawrence G|last2=Müller|first2=Hans-Georg|last3=Liu|first3=Xueli|last4=Wang|first4=Yue|last5=Carey|first5=James R|title=The symmetry of longevity|journal=Journal of Gerontology: Biological Sciences|date=October 2005|volume=60|issue=10|pages=1233–1237|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2611956/pdf/nihms47754.pdf|pmc=2611956|accessdate=19 February 2016|pmid=16282553|doi=10.1093/gerona/60.10.1233}}</ref>
== In sexual selection ==
=== Mate attraction === Symmetry has been shown to affect [[physical attractiveness]].<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Wade | first1 = T. J. | title = The Relationships between Symmetry and Attractiveness and Mating Relevant Decisions and Behavior: A Review | doi = 10.3390/sym2021081 | journal = Symmetry | volume = 2 | issue = 2 | pages = 1081–1098 | year = 2010 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> Those with lower levels of fluctuating asymmetry (FA) are often rated as more attractive.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Grammer|first1=Karl|last2=Thornhill|first2=Randy|title=Human (Homo sapiens) Facial Attractiveness and Sexual Selection: The Role of Symmetry and Averageness|journal=Journal of Comparative Psychology|date=1994|volume=108|issue=3|pages=233–242|doi=10.1037/0735-7036.108.3.233}}</ref> Various studies have supported this. The relationship between FA and mate attraction has been studied in both males and females. As FA reflects developmental stability and quality, it has been suggested that we prefer those as more attractive/with low FA because it signals traits such as health and intelligence.<ref name=":4">Gangestad, S. W., Thornhill, R., Yeo, R. A. (1994). Facial attractiveness, developmental stability, and fluctuating asymmetry. Ethology & Sociology, 15, 73-85.</ref>
Research has shown that the female partners of men with lower levels of FA experience a higher number of copulatory [[orgasm]]s, compared to the female partners of males with higher levels of FA.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Thornhill|first1=Randy|last2=Gangestad|first2=Steven W.|last3=Comer|first3=Randall|title=Human female orgasm and mate fluctuating asymmetry|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=1995|volume=50|pages=1601–1615|doi=10.1016/0003-3472(95)80014-X|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/000334729580014X/1-s2.0-000334729580014X-main.pdf?_tid=39e4c112-cf66-11e5-9f15-00000aab0f26&acdnat=1455047547_06155d3797a6e282aacb0cf594226466|accessdate=9 February 2016}}</ref> Other studies have also found that the voices of men and women with low fluctuating asymmetry are rated as more attractive,<ref name="FA and voice attractiveness, hughes study">{{cite journal|last1=Hughes|first1=Susan M.|last2=Harrison|first2=Marissa A.|last3=Gallup|first3=Gordon G. Jr.|title=The sound of symmetry: Voice as a marker of developmental instability|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=May 2002|volume=23|pages=173–180|doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(01)00099-X|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S109051380100099X/1-s2.0-S109051380100099X-main.pdf?_tid=fcab4eec-0971-11e6-a092-00000aacb35d&acdnat=1461429765_e3e5bdfb34881ae60c5042010bf4c838|accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Little | first1 = A. C. | last2 = Jones | first2 = B. C. | last3 = DeBruine | first3 = L. M. | year = 2011 | title = Facial attractiveness: evolutionary based research | url = | journal = Philosophical Transactions of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences | volume = 366 | issue = | pages = 1638–1659 | doi=10.1098/rstb.2010.0404| pmc = 3130383 }}</ref> suggesting that voice may be indicative of developmental stability. Research has shown attractiveness ratings of men's scent are negatively correlated with FA, but FA is unrelated to attractiveness ratings for women's scent, and women's preferences for the scent of more symmetric men appears limited to the most fertile phases of the [[menstrual cycle]].<ref name="FA and scent attractiveness">{{cite journal|last1=Thornhill|first1=Randy|last2=Gangestad|first2=Steven, W.|title=The scent of symmetry: A human sex pheromone that signals fitness?|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=May 1999|volume=20|issue=3|pages=175–201|doi=10.1016/S1090-5138(99)00005-7|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513899000057/1-s2.0-S1090513899000057-main.pdf?_tid=d9aec3a2-0975-11e6-9c3b-00000aab0f26&acdnat=1461431425_ace772727e2cc5c2ba29c6a060cfb30c|accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref> However, other research has failed to find changes in women's preferences for low FA across the menstrual cycle.<ref name="no link between FA preferences and menstrual cycle phase">{{cite journal|last1=Cárdenas|first1=Rodrigo Andrés|last2=Harris|first2=Lauren Julius|title=Do women's preferences for symmetry change across the menstrual cycle?|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=March 2007|volume=28|issue=2|pages=96–105|doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2006.08.003|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513806000687/1-s2.0-S1090513806000687-main.pdf?_tid=79119f8c-0976-11e6-8b5d-00000aacb35e&acdnat=1461431692_060e5e8f1e7fa21e2a17548c77a804f1|accessdate=23 April 2016}}</ref> Facial symmetry has been positively correlated with higher occurrences of [[sexual selection|mating]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Thornhill|first1=R|last2=Gangestad|first2=S|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and human sexual behaviour|journal=Psychological Science|date=1994|volume=5|pages=297–302|doi=10.1111/j.1467-9280.1994.tb00629.x}}</ref> Also, one study used 3-D scans of male and female bodies, and showed videos of these scans to a group of individuals who rated the bodies on attractiveness. It was found that, for both males and females, lower levels of FA were associated with higher attractiveness ratings. It was also found that sex-typical joint configurations were rated as more attractive and linked to lower FA in men, but not women.<ref name="FA and body attractiveness">{{cite journal|last1=Brown|first1=William M.|last2=Price|first2=Michael E.|last3=Kang|first3=Jinsheng|last4=Pound|first4=Nicholas|last5=Zhao|first5=Yue|last6=Yu|first6=Hui|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and preferences for sex-typical bodily characteristics|journal=PNAS|date=September 2008|volume=105|issue=35|pages=12938–12943|doi=10.1073/pnas.0710420105|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/105/35/12938.full.pdf|accessdate=25 March 2016|pmid=18711125|pmc=2529114}}</ref> Men with higher FA have been shown to have higher levels of oxidative stress and lower levels of attractiveness.<ref name="Oxidative stress and FA in men" /> Research has also provided evidence that FA is linked to [[extra-pair copulation]], as women have been shown to prefer men with lower levels of FA as extra-pair partners.<ref name="FA and extrapair copulation">{{cite journal|last1=Gangestad|first1=Steven W.|last2=Thornhill|first2=Randy|title=The evolutionary psychology of extrapair sex: The role of fluctuating asymmetry|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=1997|volume=18|pages=69–88|doi=10.1016/s1090-5138(97)00003-2}}</ref> However, the literature is mixed regarding the relationship between attractiveness and FA. For example, in one study, altering images of faces to in a way that reduced asymmetry led to observers rating such faces as less, rather than more, attractive.<ref name="FA not linked to greater attractiveness">{{cite journal|last1=Swaddle|first1=John P.|last2=Cuthill|first2=Innes C.|title=Asymmetry and human facial attractiveness: Symmetry may not always be beautiful|journal=Proceedings: Biological Sciences|date=July 1995|volume=261|issue=1360|pages=111–116|doi=10.1098/rspb.1995.0124|url=http://jpswad.people.wm.edu/Swaddle%20and%20Cuthill%201995%20ProcRSocB.pdf|accessdate=25 March 2016}}</ref> Research by Van Dongen also found FA to be unrelated to attractiveness, physical strength and level of masculinity in both men and women.<ref name="Facial masculinity not linked to FA">{{cite journal|last1=Van Dongen|first1=Stefan|title=Associations among facial masculinity, physical strength, fluctuating asymmetry and attractiveness in young men and women|journal=Annals of Human Biology|date=2014|volume=41|issue=3|pages=205–213|doi=10.3109/03014460.2013.847120}}<!--|accessdate=25 March 2016--></ref> [[File:Panorpa japonica1.jpg|thumb|FA in Japanese scorpionflies (''Panorpa japonica'') is linked to fighting and mating success.]]
===Sexual selection in non-human animals=== Many non-human animals have been shown to be able to distinguish between potential partners, based upon levels of FA. As with humans, lower levels of FA are seen in the most reproductively successful members of species. For instance, FA of male forewing length seem to have an important role in successful mating for many insect species, such as dark-wing damselflies and Japanese [[Mecoptera|scorpionflies]]. In the dark-winged [[damselfly]] (''Calopteryx maculate''), successfully mating male flies showed significantly lower levels of FA in their forewings than unsuccessful males,<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Beck|first1=Michelle L.|last2=Pruett-Jones|first2=Stephen|title=Fluctuating asymmetry, sexual selection, and survivorship in male dark-winged damselflies.|journal=Ethology|date=2002|volume=108|issue=9|pages=779–791|doi=10.1046/j.1439-0310.2002.00814.x}}</ref> while for Japanese scorpionflies, FA levels are a good predictor for the outcome of fights between males in that more symmetrical males won significantly more fights.<ref name=":0">{{cite journal|last1=Thornhill|first1=R.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and the mating system of the japanese scorpionfly, panorpa japonica.|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=1992|volume=44|issue=5|pages=867–879|doi=10.1016/s0003-3472(05)80583-4}}</ref> Other animals also show similar patterns, for example, many species of butterfly, males with lower levels of FA tended to live longer and flew more actively, allowing them to have more reproductive success.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Tsubaki|first1=Y.|last2=Matsumoto|first2=K.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and male mating success in a sphragis-bearing butterfly luehdorfia japonica (lepidoptera: Papilionidae).|journal=Journal of Insect Behavior|date=1998|volume=11|issue=4|pages=571–582|doi=10.1023/a:1022371531263}}</ref> Also, female swallows have been shown to prefer longer, and more symmetrical tails as a cue for mate choice. Therefore, the males with longer and more symmetrical tails show higher levels of reproductive success with more attractive females.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Møller|first1=A. P.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry in male sexual ornaments may reliable reveal male quality.|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=1990|volume=40|issue=6|pages=1185–1187|doi=10.1016/s0003-3472(05)80187-3}}</ref> In red deer, sexual selection has effected antler development, in that larger and more symmetrical antlers are favoured in males at prime mating age.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mateos|first1=C.|last2=Alarcos|first2=S.|last3=Carranza|first3=J.|last4=Sánchez-Prieto|first4=C. B.|last5=Valencia|first5=J.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry of red deer antlers negatively relates to individual condition and proximity to prime age.|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=2008|volume=75|issue=5|pages=1629–1640|doi=10.1016/j.anbehav.2007.10.016}}</ref>
However, some evidence for the effects of sexual selection of FA levels have been inconsistent, suggesting that the relationship between FA and sexual selection may be more complex than originally thought. For instance, in the lekking black grouse and red junglefowl, no correlations were found between FA and mating success.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rintamäki|first1=P. T.|last2=Alatalo|first2=R. V.|last3=Höglund|first3=J.|last4=Lundberg|first4=A.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and copulation success in lekking black grouse.|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=1997|volume=54|issue=2|pages=265–269|doi=10.1006/anbe.1996.0434}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ligon|first1=J. D.|last2=Kimball|first2=R.|last3=Merola-Zwartjes|first3=M.|title=Mate choice by female red junglefowl: The issues of multiple ornaments and fluctuating asymmetry.|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=1998|volume=55|issue=1|pages=41–50|doi=10.1006/anbe.1997.0582}}</ref> Furthermore, when manipulating paradise whydahs' tails to be more and less symmetrical, females showed no preferences for more symmetrical tails (but they did show preferences for longer tails).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Oakes|first1=E. J.|last2=Barnard|first2=P.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and mate choice in paradise whydahs, vidua pparadisaea: An experimental manipulation.|journal=Animal Behaviour|date=1994|volume=48|issue=4|pages=937–943|doi=10.1006/anbe.1994.1319}}</ref>
==Other associated factors ==
=== Intelligence === Through research, fluctuating asymmetry (FA) has been found to have a negative [[correlation]] to [[psychometrics|measurements of human traits]] such as [[working memory]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Yeo|first=RA|author2=Hill, D |author3=Campbell, R |author4=Vigil, J |author5=Brooks, WM |title=Developmental instability and working memory ability in children: a magnetic resonance spectroscopy investigation.|journal=Developmental Neuropsychology|year=2000|volume=17|issue=2|pages=143–59|doi=10.1207/S15326942DN1702_01|pmid=10955200|url=http://www.informaworld.com/smpp/content~db=all~content=a784400620}}</ref> and [[intelligence]], such that individuals showing greater asymmetry have lower IQ scores.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Furlow|first=FB|author2=Armijo-Prewitt, T |author3=Gangestad, SW |author4=Thornhill, R |title=Fluctuating asymmetry and psychometric intelligence.|journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]]|date=1997-06-22|volume=264|issue=1383|pages=823–9|doi=10.1098/rspb.1997.0115|pmid=9265189|url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/264/1383/823.short |pmc=1688437}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bates|first=T|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and intelligence|journal=Intelligence|date=1 January 2007|volume=35|issue=1|pages=41–46|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2006.03.013|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160289606000353}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Prokosch|first=M|author2=Yeo, R |author3=Miller, G |title=Intelligence tests with higher -loadings show higher correlations with body symmetry: Evidence for a general fitness factor mediated by developmental stability|journal=Intelligence|date=1 April 2005|volume=33|issue=2|pages=203–213|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2004.07.007}}</ref> As FA links with both intelligence and facial attractiveness, it is possible that our perceptions of attractiveness have evolved based upon developmental quality, which includes traits such as intelligence and health.<ref name=":4"/> However, some literature shows no such correlations between FA and intelligence.<ref name=":7" /> A meta-analysis of the research covering this topic demonstrated that whilst published studies largely report negative correlations, unpublished studies often find no association between FA and intelligence.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Banks|first=George C.|last2=Batchelor|first2=John H.|last3=McDaniel|first3=Michael A.|date=2010-07-01|title=Smarter people are (a bit) more symmetrical: A meta-analysis of the relationship between intelligence and fluctuating asymmetry|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0160289610000310|journal=Intelligence|volume=38|issue=4|pages=393–401|doi=10.1016/j.intell.2010.04.003}}</ref>
=== Personality === Research into FA suggests that there may be some correlation to specific personality factors, in particular, the [[Big Five personality traits]]. From a general view, one would expect someone who is more symmetrical (usually meaning greater attractiveness), to be high on agreeableness, [[conscientiousness]], [[Extraversion and introversion|extraversion]] and openness, and low on [[neuroticism]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Tartaglia|first = Stefano|last2 = Rollero|first2 = Chiara|date = 2015-11-27|title = The Effects of Attractiveness and Status on Personality Evaluation|url = http://ejop.psychopen.eu/article/view/896|journal = Europe’s Journal of Psychology|volume = 11|issue = 4|pages = 677–690|doi = 10.5964/ejop.v11i4.896|issn = 1841-0413}}</ref> One of the most consistent findings reported is that low FA is positively associated with measures of extraversion, suggesting that more symmetrical people tend to be more extraverted than less symmetrical individuals, particularly when specifying to symmetry within the face.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last = Fink|first = Bernhard|last2 = Neave|first2 = Nick|last3 = Manning|first3 = John T.|last4 = Grammer|first4 = Karl|date = 2005-08-01|title = Facial symmetry and the ‘big-five’ personality factors|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886905000541|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|volume = 39|issue = 3|pages = 523–529|doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2005.02.002}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last = Pound|first = Nicholas|last2 = Penton-Voak|first2 = Ian S.|last3 = Brown|first3 = William M.|date = 2007-10-01|title = Facial symmetry is positively associated with self-reported extraversion|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S019188690700164X|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|volume = 43|issue = 6|pages = 1572–1582|doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2007.04.014}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last = Fink|first = Bernhard|last2 = Neave|first2 = Nick|last3 = Manning|first3 = John T.|last4 = Grammer|first4 = Karl|date = 2006-08-01|title = Facial symmetry and judgements of attractiveness, health and personality|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886906000973|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|volume = 41|issue = 3|pages = 491–499|doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2006.01.017}}</ref> A correlation has also been reported between FA and human [[Dominance hierarchy|social dominance]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Furlow|first=B |author2=Gangestad, SW |author3=Armijo-Prewitt, T|title=Developmental stability and human violence.|journal=[[Proceedings of the Royal Society B]] |date=1998-01-07|volume=265|issue=1390|pages=1–6|doi=10.1098/rspb.1998.0255|pmid=9470212|url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/265/1390/1.short|pmc=1688754}}</ref> However, research is proving less consistent with other personality factors, with some finding some weak correlations between low FA and conscientiousness and openness to experience, and others finding no significant differences between those with high or low FA.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Hope|first = David|last2 = Bates|first2 = Timothy|last3 = Penke|first3 = Lars|last4 = Gow|first4 = Alan J.|last5 = Starr|first5 = John M.|last6 = Deary|first6 = Ian J.|date = 2011-01-01|title = Fluctuating Asymmetry and personality|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886910004228|journal = Personality and Individual Differences|volume = 50|issue = 1|pages = 49–52|doi = 10.1016/j.paid.2010.08.020}}</ref>
=== Antisocial behaviours === Some studies suggest a link between FA and [[aggression]], but the evidence is mixed. In humans, criminal offenders show greater FA than nonoffenders.<ref name="FA and psychopathy" /> However, other studies report that human males with higher FA show less physical aggression<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Manning|first=J. T.|last2=Wood|first2=D.|date=1998-03-01|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and aggression in boys|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12110-998-1011-4|journal=Human Nature|language=en|volume=9|issue=1|pages=53–65|doi=10.1007/s12110-998-1011-4|issn=1045-6767}}</ref><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Furlow|first=Bryant|last2=Gangestad|first2=Steven W.|last3=Armijo-Prewitt|first3=Tara|date=1998-01-07|title=Developmental stability and human violence|url=http://rspb.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/265/1390/1|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|language=en|volume=265|issue=1390|pages=1–6|doi=10.1098/rspb.1998.0255|issn=0962-8452|pmc=1688754|pmid=9470212}}</ref> and less anger.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Muñoz-Reyes|first=José Antonio|last2=Gil-Burmann|first2=Carlos|last3=Fink|first3=Bernhard|last4=Turiegano|first4=Enrique|date=2012-11-01|title=Facial asymmetry and aggression in Spanish adolescents|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0191886912003005|journal=Personality and Individual Differences|volume=53|issue=7|pages=857–861|doi=10.1016/j.paid.2012.06.012}}</ref> Females show no association between FA and physical aggression,<ref name=":5" /> but some research has suggested that older female adolescents with higher facial FA are less hostile.<ref name=":6" /> The type of aggression being studied may account for the mixed evidence that is seen here. For example, one study found that females with higher FA demonstrated higher levels of reactive aggression in response to high levels of provocation, whereas high FA males showed more reactive aggression under low levels of provocation.<ref name="FA and reactive aggression">{{cite journal|last1=Benderlioglu|first1=Zeynep|last2=Sciulli|first2=Paul W.|last3=Nelson|first3=Randy J.|title=Fluctuating asymmetry predicts human reactive aggression|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|date=2004|volume=16|issue=4|pages=458–469|doi=10.1002/ajhb.20047}}<!--|accessdate=28 March 2016--></ref>
Research is also mixed in other animals. In Japanese [[Panorpa|scorpionflies]] (''Panorpa nipponensis'' and ''Panorpa ochraceopennis''), FA differences between members of the same sex competing for food determines the outcome of [[Interspecific competition|interspecific contests]] and aggression better than body size or ownership of food.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Thornhill|first=Randy|date=1992-05-01|title=Fluctuating asymmetry, interspecific aggression and male mating tactics in two species of Japanese scorpionflies|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00170603|journal=Behavioral Ecology and Sociobiology|language=en|volume=30|issue=5|pages=357–363|doi=10.1007/BF00170603|issn=0340-5443}}</ref> Furthermore, cannibalistic laying [[Chicken|hens]] (''Gallus gallus domesticus'') demonstrate more asymmetry than normal hens.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Yngvesson|first=Jenny|last2=Keeling|first2=Linda J.|date=2001-03-01|title=Body size and fluctuating asymmetry in relation to cannibalistic behaviour in laying hens|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0003347200916166|journal=Animal Behaviour|volume=61|issue=3|pages=609–615|doi=10.1006/anbe.2000.1616}}</ref> However, this link between FA and aggression in hens is questionable, as victimised hens also showed greater asymmetry. Furthermore, when [[Prenatal development|prenatally]] injecting hen eggs with excess [[serotonin]] (5-HT), the hens later exhibited more FA at 18 weeks of age, but displayed less aggressive behaviours. It is suggested that the stress introduced during early embryonic stages via certain factors (such as excess serotonin) may create developmental instability, causing phenotypic and behavioural variations (such as increased or decreased aggression).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dennis|first=Rachel L.|last2=Fahey|first2=Alan G.|last3=Cheng|first3=Heng W.|date=2013-03-01|title=Alterations to Embryonic Serotonin Change Aggression and Fearfulness|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ab.21459/abstract|journal=Aggressive Behavior|language=en|volume=39|issue=2|pages=91–98|doi=10.1002/ab.21459|issn=1098-2337}}</ref>
===Ageing===
In old age, facial symmetry has been associated with better [[Aging brain|cognitive aging]], as lower levels of FA have been associated with higher intelligence and more efficient information processing in older men.<ref name="FA and cognitive aging">{{cite journal|last1=Penke|first1=Lars|last2=Bates|first2=Timothy C|last3=Gow|first3=Alan J|last4=Pattie|first4=Alison|last5=Starr|first5=John M|last6=Jones|first6=Benedict C|last7=Perrett|first7=David I|last8=Deary|first8=Ian J|title=Symmetric faces are a sign of successful cognitive aging|journal=Evolution and Human Behavior|date=November 2009|volume=30|issue=6|pages=429–437|doi=10.1016/j.evolhumbehav.2009.06.001|url=http://ac.els-cdn.com/S1090513809000543/1-s2.0-S1090513809000543-main.pdf?_tid=e47f5726-d723-11e5-b37a-00000aacb35d&acdnat=1455898666_db9300ce5bbce8595f8dd1bde41f0277|accessdate=19 February 2016}}</ref> Although, it has been found that risk of mortality cannot be predicted accurately from levels of FA in photographs of older adults.<ref name="Predicting mortality from human faces">{{cite journal|last1=Dykiert|first1=Dominika|last2=Bates|first2=Timothy C|last3=Gow|first3=Alan J|last4=Penke|first4=Lars|last5=Starr|first5=John M|last6=Deary|first6=Ian J|title=Predicting mortality from human faces|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|date=2012|volume=74|issue=6|pages=560–566|doi=10.1097/PSY.0b013e318259c33f}}<!--|accessdate=19 February 2016--></ref>
=== Other factors === Additionally, FA has been shown to predict atypical asymmetry of the brain.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Davis|first1=J. T|last2=Gangestad|first2=S. W|last3=Lewine|first3=J. D|last4=Thoma|first4=R. J|last5=Yeo|first5=R. A|title=Fluctuating asymmetry and the human brain|journal=Laterality: Asymmetries of Body, Brain and Cognition|date=2002|volume=7|pages=45–58}}</ref> Research has also shown that growth rates after birth positively correlate with FA. For example, increased FA has been found in people who were currently obese.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = A trade-off between early growth rate and fluctuating asymmetry in Brazilian boys|journal = Annals of Human Biology|date = 2006-02-01|issn = 0301-4460|pmid = 16500816|pages = 112–124|volume = 33|issue = 1|doi = 10.1080/03014460500480391|first = Jonathan C. K.|last = Wells|first2 = Pedro C.|last2 = Hallal|first3 = John T.|last3 = Manning|first4 = Cesar G.|last4 = Victora}}</ref>

'''Handling qualities''' is one of the two principal regimes in the science of [[flight test]] (the other being performance). Handling qualities involves the study and evaluation of the stability and control characteristics of an aircraft. They have a critical bearing on the safety of flight and on the ease of controlling an airplane in steady flight and in maneuvers.
==Relation to stability== To understand the discipline of handling qualities, the concept of stability should be understood. Stability can be defined only when the vehicle is in trim; that is, there are no unbalanced forces or moments acting on the vehicle to cause it to deviate from steady flight. If this condition exists, and if the vehicle is disturbed, stability refers to the tendency of the vehicle to return to the trimmed condition. If the vehicle initially tends to return to a trimmed condition, it is said to be statically stable. If it continues to approach the trimmed condition without overshooting, the motion is called a subsidence. If the motion causes the vehicle to overshoot the trimmed condition, it may oscillate back and forth. If this oscillation damps out, the motion is called a damped oscillation and the vehicle is said to be dynamically stable. On the other hand, if the motion increases in amplitude, the vehicle is said to be dynamically unstable.
The theory of stability of airplanes was worked out by G. H. Bryan in [[England]] in 1904. This theory is essentially equivalent to the theory taught to aeronautical students today and was a remarkable intellectual achievement considering that at the time Bryan developed the theory, he had not even heard of the Wright brothers' first flight. Because of the complication of the theory and the tedious computations required in its use, it was rarely applied by airplane designers. Obviously, to fly successfully, pilotless airplanes had to be dynamically stable. The airplane flown by the Wright brothers, and most airplanes flown thereafter, were not stable, but by trial and error, designers developed a few planes that had satisfactory flying qualities. Many other airplanes, however, had poor flying qualities, which sometimes resulted in crashes.
==Historical development== Bryan showed that the stability characteristics of airplanes could be separated into longitudinal and lateral groups with the corresponding motions called modes of motion. These modes of motion were either aperiodic, which means that the airplane steadily approaches or diverges from a trimmed condition, or oscillatory, which means that the airplane oscillates about the trim condition. The longitudinal modes of a statically stable airplane following a disturbance were shown to consist of a long-period oscillation called the [[phugoid]] oscillation, usually with a period in seconds about one-quarter of the airspeed in miles per hour and a short-period oscillation with a period of only a few seconds. The lateral motion had three modes of motion: an aperiodic mode called the spiral mode that could be a divergence or subsidence, a heavily damped aperiodic mode called the roll subsidence, and a short-period oscillation, usually poorly damped, called the Dutch roll mode.
Some early airplane designers attempted to make airplanes that were dynamically stable, but it was found that the requirements for stability conflicted with those for satisfactory flying qualities. Meanwhile, no information was available to guide the designer as to just what characteristics should be incorporated to provide satisfactory flying qualities.
By the 1930s, there was a general feeling that airplanes should be dynamically stable, but some aeronautical engineers were starting to recognize the conflict between the requirements for stability and flying qualities. To resolve this question, Edward Warner, who was working as a consultant to the Douglas Aircraft Company on the design of the DC-4, a large four-engine transport airplane, made the first effort in the United States to write a set of requirements for satisfactory flying qualities. Dr. Warner, a member of the main committee of the [[NACA]], also requested that a flight study be made to determine the flying qualities of an airplane along the lines of the suggested requirements. This study was conducted by [[Hartley A. Soulé]] of Langley. Entitled ''Preliminary Investigation of the Flying Qualities of Airplanes'', Soulé's report showed several areas in which the suggested requirements needed revision and showed the need for more research on other types of airplanes.<ref>{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-ctX2Q-CSIC&pg=PA22&dq=Floyd+L.+Thompson&hl=en&ei=fkprTOStEoH6lwethskX&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDQQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=Floyd%20L.%20Thompson&f=false| title=Airplane stability and control: a history of the technologies that made aviation possible| authors=Malcolm J. Abzug, E. Eugene Larrabee| publisher=Cambridge University Press| year= 2002| isbn= 978-0-521-80992-4 }}</ref> As a result, a program was started by [[Robert R. Gilruth]] with [[Melvin N. Gough]] as the chief test pilot.
==Evaluation of handling qualities== The technique for the study of flying qualities requirements used by Gilruth was first to install instruments to record relevant quantities such as control positions and forces, airplane angular velocities, linear accelerations, airspeed, and altitude. Then a program of specified flight conditions and maneuvers was flown by an experienced test pilot. After the flight, data were transcribed from the records and the results were correlated with pilot opinion. This approach would be considered routine today, but it was a notable original contribution by Gilruth that took advantage of the flight recording instruments already available at Langley and the variety of airplanes available for tests under comparable conditions.
An important quantity in handling qualities measurements in turns or pull-ups is the variation of control force on the control stick or wheel with the value of acceleration normal to the flight direction expressed in g units. This quantity is usually called the force per g.
==Relation to Spacecraft== Handling qualities are those characteristics of a flight vehicle that govern the ease and precision with which a pilot is able to perform a flying task.<ref>Cooper, G.E. and Harper, R.P., “The Use of Pilot Rating in the Evaluation of Aircraft Handling Qualities,” NASA TN D-5153, April 1969</ref> The way in which particular vehicle factors affect handling qualities has been studied in aircraft for decades,<ref> Gilruth, R.R., “Requirements for Satisfactory Flying Qualities of Airplanes,” NACA TR 755, 1943</ref> and reference standards for the handling qualities of both fixed-wing aircraft<ref> “Military Standard, Flying Qualities of Piloted Airplanes,” MIL-STD-1797, March 1987.</ref> and rotary-wing aircraft<ref>Aeronautical Design Standard, Performance Specification: Handling Qualities Requirements for Military Rotorcraft,” ADS-33, May 1996</ref> have been developed and are now in common use. These standards define a subset of the dynamics and control design space that provides good handling qualities for a given vehicle type and flying task. A new generation of spacecraft now under development by NASA to replace the Space Shuttle and return astronauts to the Moon will have a manual control capability for several mission tasks, and the ease and precision with which pilots can execute these tasks will have an important effect on performance, mission risk and training costs. No reference standards currently exist for handling qualities of piloted spacecraft.

Abzug] * Stengel R F: [http://www.princeton.edu/~stengel/FlightDynamics.html Flight Dynamics]. [[Princeton University Press]] 2004, {{ISBN|0-691-11407-2}}.

'''Friedrich A. Kittler''' (June 12, 1943 – October 18, 2011) was a literary scholar and a media theorist. His works relate to [[Mass media|media]], [[technology]], and the [[military]].
==Biography== Friedrich Adolf Kittler was born in 1943 in [[Rochlitz]] in [[Saxony]]. His family fled with him to [[West Germany]] in 1958, where from 1958 to 1963 he went to a [[natural sciences]] and [[modern languages]] ''[[Gymnasium (school)|Gymnasium]]'' in [[Lahr]] in the [[Black Forest]], and thereafter, until 1972, he studied [[German studies]], [[Romance languages|Romance]] [[philology]] and [[philosophy]] at the [[Albert Ludwigs University of Freiburg]] in [[Freiburg im Breisgau]]. During his studies, he was especially influenced by the writings of [[Jacques Lacan]], [[Michel Foucault]] and [[Martin Heidegger]].
In 1976, Kittler received his doctorate in philosophy after a thesis on the poet [[Conrad Ferdinand Meyer]]. Between 1976 and 1986 he worked as academic assistant at the university's ''Deutsches Seminar''. In 1984, he earned his [[Habilitation]] in the field of Modern German Literary History.
He had several stints as a Visiting Assistant Professor or Visiting Professor at universities in the [[United States]], such as the [[University of California, Berkeley]], the [[University of California, Santa Barbara]] and [[Stanford University]].
From 1986 to 1990, he headed the [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft|DFG's]] ''Literature and Media Analysis'' project in [[Kassel]] and in 1987 he was appointed Professor of Modern German Studies at the [[Ruhr University]]. In 1993 he was appointed to the chair for Media Aesthetics and History at the [[Humboldt University of Berlin]].
In 1993, Kittler was awarded the "Siemens Media Arts Prize" (''Siemens-Medienkunstpreis'') by [[Zentrum für Kunst und Medientechnologie|ZKM Karlsruhe]] (''Zentrum für Kunst und Medientechnologie'', or "Centre for Art and Media Technology") for his research in the field of media theory.<ref>[http://on1.zkm.de/zkm/stories/storyReader%241107 Siemens Medienkunstpreis 1993/ Friedrich Kittle] ZKM. Museum für Neue Kunst.</ref>
He was recognized in 1996 as a Distinguished Scholar at [[Yale University]] and in 1997 as a Distinguished Visiting Professor at [[Columbia University]] in [[New York City|New York]]. Kittler was a member of the Hermann von Helmholtz Centre for Culture and the research group ''Bild Schrift Zahl'' ("Picture Writing Number") (DFG).
Among Kittler's theses was his tendency to argue, with a mixture of polemicism, apocalypticism, erudition, and humor, that technological conditions were closely bound up with epistemology and ontology itself. This claim and his style of argumention is aptly summed up in his dictum "Nur was schaltbar ist, ist überhaupt"—a phrase that could be translated as "Only that which is switchable, exists" or more freely, "Only that which can be switched, can be." This phrase plays both on the concept that in principle any representation can be presented according to the on/off binary logic of computing. Kittler goes one step further by suggesting that, conversely, anything that can't be "switched" can't really "be," at least under current technical conditions. He invoked this doctrine on his deathbed in 2011. Dying in a hospital in Berlin and sustained only by a medical instruments, his final words were "Alle Apparate ausschalten", which translates as "switch off all apparatuses".<ref>[http://www.lrb.co.uk/blog/2011/11/09/tom-mccarthy/kittler-and-the-sirens/ London Review of Books article].</ref>
==Work== Friedrich Kittler is influential in the new approach to [[media influence|media theory]] that grew popular starting in the 1980s, [[new media]] ({{lang-de|technische Medien}}, which translates roughly to "technical media"). Kittler's central project is to "prove to the human sciences [...] their technological-media ''a priori''" ([[Hartmut Winkler]]), or in his own words: "Driving the human out of the humanities",<ref>This loses something in the translation, since "spirit" is "Geist" in [[German language|German]], and "[[humanities]]" is "Geisteswissenschaften", or "spiritual sciences".</ref> a title that he gave a work that he published in 1980.
Kittler sees an autonomy in technology and therefore disagrees with [[Marshall McLuhan]]'s reading of the media as "extensions of man": "Media are not pseudopods for extending the human body. They follow the logic of escalation that leaves us and written history behind it. (Kittler in ''Geschichte der Kommunikationsmedien''. In: Jörg Huber, Alois Martin Müller (publishers): ''Raum und Verfahren''.)
Consequently, he sees in writing literature, in writing programmes and in burning structures into [[silicon chip]]s a complete continuum: "As we know and simply do not say, no human being writes anymore. [...] Today, human writing runs through inscriptions burnt into silicon by electronic lithography [...]. The last historic act of writing may thus have been in the late seventies when a team of Intel engineers [plotted] the hardware architecture of their first integrated microprocessor." (Kittler, ''Es gibt keine Software''. In: ders.: ''Draculas Vermächtnis. Technische Schriften''.)
{{cquote|And Kittler is a good friend of mine – I sponsored a chair at the Humboldt University for two years. He is not mainstream. Historians of music come and say, “But he did not write his thesis on [[Giovanni Pierluigi da Palestrina|Palestrina]].” And all the professors of philosophy say, “But did he write a thesis on [[Kant]] or Heidegger?” No, Kittler is a mixture: Kittler is in between philosophy, the history of music, computer science, and media theory. That’s why he is completely outstanding. We have some fundamental heroes in Germany, really outstanding people on the level of [[Deleuze]], [[Derrida]], Lacan, [[Georges Bataille|Bataille]] … Among these are [[Bazon Brock]], Friedrich Kittler, [[Peter Sloterdijk|Sloterdijk]], [[Horst Bredekamp|Bredekamp]], or [[Hans Belting]]. These people will last longer than I will in this book. In 50 years, each of them will be known as people who had been very sensitive to changes of the media.—[[Hubert Burda]], 2011<ref>[[David Woodard|Woodard, D.]], "In Media Res," ''[[032c]]'', Sum 2011, [http://032c.com/2012/in-media-res/ pp. 180–189].</ref>{{rp|180–189}}}}
