[[File:Logo HCM.jpg|thumb|The official logo of the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics.]]
The '''Hausdorff Center for Mathematics''' ('''HCM''') is a research center in [[Bonn]], formed by the four mathematical institutes of the [[Rheinische Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität Bonn]] (Mathematical Institute, Institute for Applied Mathematics, Institute for Numerical Simulation, Research Institute for Discrete Mathematics), the [[Max Planck Institute for Mathematics]] (MPIM), and the Institute for Social and Economic Sciences.<ref>[https://www.hcm.uni-bonn.de/about-hcm/organization/participating-institutes/ Participating institutes] at the website of the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics, retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref>
== History == The Hausdorff Center was established in 2006 as one of the seventeen national [[German Universities Excellence Initiative#Winners: Clusters of Excellence|Clusters of Excellence]] that were part of the [[German Universities Excellence Initiative|German government's Excellence Initiative]].<ref>[http://www.dfg.de/service/presse/pressemitteilungen/2006/pressemitteilung_nr_54/index.html Press release No. 54], at the Website of the [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]] (English: German Research Foundation), retrieved 2017-10-24</ref> It was officially opened with a colloquium on 19 and 20 January 2007. In 2012, a second funding period was granted. The Hausdorff Center is the only cluster of excellence in the area of mathematics in Germany.<ref>[http://www.dfg.de/en/research_funding/programmes/list/index.jsp?id=EXC List of the Clusters of Excellence] at the Website of the [[Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft]] (English: German Research Foundation), retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref>
The center is named after the mathematician [[Felix Hausdorff]] (born 8 November 1868; died 26 January 1942).
== Organization == The coordinator of the HCM is [[Karl-Theodor Sturm]].<ref>[http://www.hcm.uni-bonn.de/about-hcm/organisation/management/ Management of the HCM] at the website of the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics, retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref> Altogether, about 70 professors from Bonn are affiliated with the HCM: all professors for Mathematics, of the MPI, and for Theoretical Economy.<ref>[http://www.hcm.uni-bonn.de/about-hcm/ About HCM] at the website of the Hausdorff Center for Mathematics, retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref> These include the director of the MPI, [[Gerd Faltings]], who was awarded the [[Fields Medal]] in 1986,<ref>[http://www.mathunion.org/general/prizes/fields/prizewinners/ List of Fields medallists] at the website of the [[International Mathematical Union]], retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref> and [[Peter Scholze]], who was awarded the Fields Medal in 2018.
The Hausdorff Research Institute for Mathematics (HIM), the Bonn International Graduate School in Mathematics (BIGS), and the Hausdorff School for Advanced Studies in Mathematics are part of the Hausdorff Center:
* The ''Hausdorff Research Institute for Mathematics (HIM)'' organizes international long-term programs and fosters cooperations between German mathematicians and internationally renowned scientists in mathematics and mathematical economics. It also runs specific programs for young scientists. Director of the HIM is [[Christoph Thiele]].<ref>[http://www.him.uni-bonn.de Website of the Hausdorff Research Institute for Mathematics], retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref> * The ''Bonn International Graduate School in Mathematics (BIGS)'' supports the scientific development of PhD students. Director of the BIGS is [[Barbara Niethammer]].<ref>[http://www.bigs-math.uni-bonn.de/ Website of the Bonn International Graduate School in Mathematics], retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref> * The ''Hausdorff School for Advanced Studies in Mathematics'' is a training program for postdoctoral researchers based in Germany and worldwide. It fosters the systematic qualification of young scientists.<ref>[https://www.hcm.uni-bonn.de/events/eventpages/2016/hausdorff-school/ Website of the Hausdorff School for Advanced Studies in Mathematics], retrieved 2017-10-24.</ref> Director is [[Patrik Ferrari]].

{{Infobox organization |name = History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group |image = |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |abbreviation = HoMBRG |motto = |formation = {{Start date|1990}} |extinction = |type = Historical research body |status = |purpose = |headquarters = |leader_title = |leader_name = |leader_title2 = |leader_name2 = |leader_title3 = |leader_name3 = |leader_title4 = |leader_name4 = |key_people = |main_organ = |parent_organization = [[Queen Mary University of London]] |affiliations = |budget = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |website = {{Url|http://histmodbiomed.org/}} |former name = History of Twentieth Century Medicine Group }}
The '''History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group''' ('''HoMBRG''') is an academic organisation specialising in recording and publishing the [[oral history]] of twentieth and twenty-first century [[biomedicine]]. It was established in 1990 as the Wellcome Trust's '''History of Twentieth Century Medicine Group''',<ref name="MHL2013">{{cite web|url=http://www.medicalheritage.org/2013/03/13/the-mhl-welcomes-a-new-content-contributor-2/|title=The MHL Welcomes a New Content Contributor|date=13 March 2013|publisher=[[Medical Heritage Library]]|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref> and reconstituted in October 2010 as part of the School of History <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.history.qmul.ac.uk/research/research-centres|title=Research Centres - School of History|website=www.history.qmul.ac.uk|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref> at [[Queen Mary University of London]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Trust|first1=Wellcome|title=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group celebrates 21 years of innovation|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/2014}}</ref><ref>http://www.qmul.ac.uk/media/news/items/hss/140113.htm</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Trust|first1=Wellcome|title=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group celebrates 21 years of innovation|url=http://www.wellcome.ac.uk/News/2014/WTP057432.htm |publisher=[[Wellcome Trust]] |accessdate=29 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref>
== History == The project originated as The [[Wellcome Trust]]'s History of Twentieth Century Medicine Group, and later functioned as the Academic Unit of the Wellcome Institute for the History of Medicine. It was originally established at the Royal College of Physicians in 1990 and comprised Sir [[Christopher Booth]] (the Harveian Librarian) and Professor [[Tilli Tansey]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Aronson|first1=Jeff |title=Wellcome witnesses to twentieth-century medicine |journal=Cambridge Journal Medical History |date=July 1998 |volume=42 |issue=3 |pages=404–405 |pmc=1044055}}</ref> Its purpose was to devise ways of stimulating historians, scientists & clinicians to discuss, preserve and write the history of recent biomedicine. The Group's activities were originally overseen by a Programme Committee, which included professional historians of medicine, practising scientists and clinicians.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Pickstone|first1=John V.|title=A brief history of medical history|url=http://www.history.ac.uk/makinghistory/resources/articles/history_of_medicine.html |publisher=Making History|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> From 2000–2010 it was a constituent part of the Wellcome Trust Centre for the History of Medicine at University College London. In October 2010 it moved to the School of History, Queen Mary’s University, London. In 2011 the Group received a Strategic Award from the Wellcome Trust to embark upon a new project, "Makers of Modern Biomedicine".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Society|first1=The Physiological|title=Hidden voices and human stories|url=https://www.physoc.org/news/2012/hidden-voices-and-human-stories |publisher=The Physiological Society|accessdate=29 May 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://search.wellcomelibrary.org/iii/encore/search/C__SHistory+of+Biomedicine+Research+Group.+__Orightresult;jsessionid=F0C74ABF559F644E711241B44A7FAD7E?lang=eng&suite=cobalt|title=Wellcome Library Encore -- History+of+Biomedicine+Research+Group.+|website=search.wellcomelibrary.org|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Culture24-2012">{{cite web|url=http://www.culture24.org.uk/science-and-nature/medicine/art375045|title=Five-year, £1.4 million project to reveal "unsung heroes" of biomedicine|date=31 January 2012|work=Culture24|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://genmedhist.eshg.org/news-events/|title=News & Events|work=Genetics and Medicine Historical Network|publisher=[[Cardiff University]]|accessdate=6 May 2017 |quote=The History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group, based at Queen Mary, University of London, continue to build upon their work documenting the recent history of clinical genetics research and practice. }}</ref><ref name="UniOfSurrey">{{cite web|url=http://www.surrey.ac.uk/features/pioneering-work-biomedicine-celebrated|title=Pioneering work in biomedicine celebrated|date=25 August 2015|publisher=[[University of Surrey]]|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref>
== Outputs ==
An archive of oral and written history, plus videoed interviews, has been compiled by the HoMBRG and consists of three projects: Witness Seminars, Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History and SAD at 30. All material and documentation related to the project is deposited with the Wellcome Library. The resultant publications are open access,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Medical Humanities|first1=Centre for|title=New Open Access Publication – The Development of Narrative Practices in Medicine c.1960–c.2000|url=http://centreformedicalhumanities.org/new-open-access-publication-the-development-of-narrative-practices-in-medicine-c-1960-c-2000/ |publisher=[[Durham University]] |accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> and made freely available online via the HoMBRG website, a partnership with the Medical Heritage Library,<ref>{{cite web|last1=Library|first1=Medical History|title=The MHL Welcomes a New Content Contributor|url=http://www.medicalheritage.org/2013/03/the-mhl-welcomes-a-new-content-contributor-2/|website=Medical History Library|publisher=Medical History Library|accessdate=29 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> and iTunes.<ref name="apple.com">{{cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/gb/itunes-u/todays-neuroscience-tomorrows/id557520467?mt=10|title=Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History - Professor Sir Peter Mansfield - Free Podcast by Queen Mary University of London on Apple Podcasts|website=Apple Podcasts|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref>
The topics covered by the archive fall broadly into five themes: [[clinical genetics]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Historical Network|first1=Genetics and Medicine|title=The History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group, based at Queen Mary, University of London, continue to build upon their work documenting the recent history of clinical genetics research and practice|url=http://www.genmedhist.info/news-and-events/|accessdate=31 May 2015|publisher=Cardiff University|ref=none}}</ref> [[neuroscience]], global health and [[infectious diseases]], [[medical technologies]] and ethics of research and practice.
Resources from the archive are online at The History of Modern Biomedicine Archive<ref>{{cite web|title=The History of Modern Biomedicine|url=http://histmodbiomed.org/article/projects |publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|accessdate=31 May 2015}}</ref> and the internet archive<ref>https://archive.org/search.php?query=publisher%3A%22London%3A+The+History+of+Modern+Biomedicine+Research+Group+at+UCL%22</ref>
=== Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History ===
The Group's 'Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History' initiative (2006-2008) was funded by a Wellcome Trust Public Engagement grant. It recorded interviews on three themes, [[neuropharmacology]], [[psychiatry]]/[[neuropsychology]], and [[neuroimaging]], with twelve neuroscientists, including [[Geoffrey Burnstock]], [[Salvador Moncada]], [[Michael Rutter]] and [[Uta Frith]].<ref name="TNTH">{{cite web|url=http://www.histmodbiomed.org/article/about-todays-neuroscience-tomorrows-history|title=About Today's Neuroscience, Tomorrow's History|publisher=HoMBRG|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref>
=== The Witness Seminars ===
A series of [[witness seminar]]s began in 1993, with regular meetings being held, about four per year. These recorded the voices of those who have contributed, in diverse ways, to the development of modern [[biomedicine]], using oral history methodology. The aim is to make the series widely available for education, research and outreach purposes.<ref name=JonesEM>{{cite book|editor1-last=Jones|editor1-first=E.M.|editor2-last=Tansey|editor2-first=E.M.|title=Monoclonal Antibodies to Migraine: Witnesses to Modern Biomedicine, An A-Z|date=2014|publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|location=London|isbn=978 0 90223 895 4|pages=223|ref=none|language=English}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://patient.info/forums/discuss/migraine-diagnosis-treatment-and-understanding-270038|title=Migraine: Diagnosis, Treatment and Understanding - Migraine - Patient|website=patient.info|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Jones2016">{{cite journal|last=Jones|first=Emma M.|year=2016|title=A witness seminar on the history of the Human Gene Mapping Workshops|journal=Gene|volume=589|issue=2|pages=123–126|issn=0378-1119|doi=10.1016/j.gene.2016.02.030|pmc=4925380}}</ref><ref name="Messenger">{{cite web|url=https://waste-management-world.com/a/an-oral-history-of-waste-management-by-university-historians-in-london|title=An Oral History of Waste Management by University Historians in London|last=Messenger|first=Ben|date=15 January 2016|work=Waste Management World|accessdate=6 May 2017}}</ref><ref name="Tansey2016">{{cite journal|last1=Tansey|first1=T |first2=A. |last2=Wilkinson |first3=A. |last3=Yabsley |first4=A. |last4=Zarros |year=2016|title=Physiology at the heart of modern biomedicine: Evidence through oral testimonies|journal=Proceedings of the Physiological Society|publisher=[[The Physiological Society]]|volume=37}}</ref> The results are published online,<ref>{{Cite book| publisher = Routledge| isbn = 978-1-134-70170-4| last1 = McConville| first1 = Sean| last2 = Bryson| first2 = Anna| title = The Routledge Guide to Interviewing: Oral History, Social Enquiry and Investigation |year=2013 |page=149}}</ref> with most edited transcripts appearing within 18 months.<ref name=JonesEM/>
Witness Seminar participants have included [[Usama Abdulla]], [[Thomas Brown (medical physicist)|Thomas Brown]], Professor [[Dugald Cameron]], Professor [[Stuart Campbell (obstetrician)|Stuart Campbell]], [[John Fleming (physician)|John Fleming]], Professor [[John MacVicar]], Professor [[Peter N.T. Wells|Peter Wells]], Dr [[James Willocks]], Sir [[Douglas Black (physician)|Douglas Black]], Sir [[John Gray (physiologist)|John Gray]], Sir [[Raymond Hoffenberg]], Dr [[Sheila Howarth]], Professor [[Peter Lachmann]], Sir [[Patrick Nairne]], Professor Sir [[Stanley Peart]] and Dr [[Peter Williams (physician)|Peter Williams]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Young|first1=Jacy|title=New Neuroscience & Applied Psych History Resources|url=http://ahp.apps01.yorku.ca/?p=3136 |publisher=Advances in the History of Psychology|accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref>
Each witness seminar is transcribed and published by HoMBRG.<ref>http://www.medicalheritage.org/2014/10/mhl-partner-history-of-modern-biomedicine-research-group-celebrates-21st-anniversary/</ref> Recent volumes have been edited by E M Jones, C Overy and E M Tansey. {{As of|May 2017}} there are 62 Volumes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.histmodbiomed.org/article/wellcome-witnesses-volumes |title= Wellcome Witnesses Volumes |publisher=History of Modern Biomedicine Research Group |date= |accessdate=2015-05-31}}</ref> Titles include ''The Development of Brain Banks'', ''Narrative Medicine''; ''Migraine''; ''The National Survey of Sexual Attitudes and Lifestyles'';<ref>{{cite web|last1=Social Research|first1=NatCen|title=The story of Natsal, the nation’s sex study|url=http://www.natcen.ac.uk/blog/the-story-of-natsal,-the-nation%E2%80%99s-sex-study |publisher=NatCen Social Research|accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> and ''The Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children (ALSPAC)''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Study of Parents and Children|first1=Avon Longitudinal|title=Avon Longitudinal Study of Parents and Children|url=http://www.bristol.ac.uk/alspac/ |publisher=[[Bristol University]] |accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> The publication of these works are often referred to by specialists in their fields of medical practice.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ehospice.com/Default/tabid/10686/ArticleId/3528|title=History of palliative medicine in the UK|first=|last=International|website=www.ehospice.com|accessdate=11 May 2017}}</ref>
The first two volumes were reviewed in ''[[Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine]]'' in 1999, with the comment, "Few books are so intellectually stimulating or uplifting."<ref name="BlauJN">{{cite journal|last=Blau|first=J N|year=1999|title=Wellcome Witnesses to Twentieth Century Medicine, Vols 1 and 2|journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine|volume=92|pages=206–8}} <!--PMC1297150 --></ref> Reviewing the series in the ''[[British Medical Journal]]'' in 2002, medical historian [[Irvine Loudon]] wrote, "This is oral history at its best...all the volumes make compulsive reading...they are, primarily, important historical records<ref name="Loudon2002">{{cite journal|last=Loudon|first=I.|year=2002|title=Book: Wellcome Witnesses to Twentieth Century Medicine|journal=BMJ|volume=325|issue=7372|pages=1119a–1119|issn=0959-8138|doi=10.1136/bmj.325.7372.1119/a}}</ref>
In 2014 a seminar, chaired by Professor Sir Brian Follett, with [[Norman Rosenthal]] and [[Alfred Lewy]], entitled 'The Recent History of [[Seasonal Affective Disorder]] (SAD): 30 Years of SAD' was undertaken on the topic of Seasonal Affective Disorder.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Association|first1=SAD|title=Wellcome Trust Wtness Seminar:An Important New Publication|url=http://www.sada.org.uk/sada_get_news_item.php?action=show&id=34-3-News |publisher=SAD Association|accessdate=31 May 2015|ref=none}}</ref> This resulted in a number of podcasts,<ref name="apple.com"/> and Volume 51 of the Witness Seminar publications.<ref>{{cite book|editor1-last=Overy|editor1-first=C|editor2-last=Tansey|editor2-first=E.M.|title=The Recent History Of Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)|date=2014|publisher=Queen Mary, University of London|location=London|isbn=978 0 90223 897 8|url=http://ischronobiology.org/Joomla_1.5.26-Stable-Full_Package/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=109:the-recent-history-of-seasonal-affective-disorder&catid=45:books&Itemid=68|accessdate=29 May 2015|ref=none|language=English}}</ref>
=== Clips and Conversations ===
In 2015 the Group began producing oral history interviews with notable scientists and clinicians. This material is made freely available on YouTube (in the case of video interviews) and the Group’s website, as are the transcripts of both audio and video interviews.<ref name="OHHEN">{{cite web|url=https://ohhen.wordpress.com/2017/01/29/makers-of-modern-biomedicine-testimonies-and-legacy/|title=Makers of Modern Biomedicine: Testimonies and Legacy|publisher=Oral History in Higher Education Network|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>
=== Wikidata ===
{{Wikidata property|P3885}}
As the HoMBRG project came to an end, a [[Wikimedian in Residence]] was engaged, to create [[Wikidata]] records for the publications and those people interviewed in them.<ref name="WiR">{{cite web|url=http://www.histmodbiomed.org/blog/introducing-wikimedian-residence-mr-andy-mabbett|title=Introducing Wikimedian in Residence, Mr Andy Mabbett|date=2 May 2017|publisher=HoMBRG|accessdate=16 May 2017}}</ref>

An '''interpolation''', in relation to [[literature]] and especially ancient [[manuscript]]s, is an entry or passage in a text that was not written by the original author. As there are often several generations of copies between an extant copy of an ancient text and the original, each handwritten by different scribes, there is a natural tendency for extraneous material to be inserted into such documents over time.
Interpolations originally may be inserted as an authentic explanatory note (for example, {{bracket|[[sic]]}}), but may also be included for fraudulent purposes. The forged passages and works attributed to the [[Pseudo-Isidore]] are an example of the latter. Similarly, the letters of [[Ignatius of Antioch]] were interpolated by Apollinarian heretics, three centuries after the originals were written. Charters and legal texts are also subject to [[forgery]] of this kind. In the 13th century a medieval romance, the ''[[Prose Tristan]]'', inserted another prose romance, the [[Vulgate]] ''Queste del Saint Graal'', in its entirety in order to reinterpret the Quest for the [[Holy Grail]] through the optics of the Tristan story.<ref>On the Medieval technique of manuscript ''[[interpolation]]'' and the ''Prose Tristan'', see Emmanuèle Baumgartner, "La préparation à la ''Queste del Saint Graal'' dans le ''Tristan'' en prose" in Norris Lacy, ed. ''Conjunctures'' (Amsterdam: Rodopi, 1994), pp. 1-14, Fanni Bogdanow, "L'Invention du texte, intertextualité et le problème de la transmission et de la classification de manuscrits" ''Romania'' 111 (190): 121-40 and Janina P. Traxler, "The Use and Abuse of the Grail Quest" ''Tristania'' 15 (1994): 23-31. Gaston Paris, in 1897, also noted the interpolation of a verse romance on [[Brunor]] in ''Prose Tristan''.</ref>
However, most interpolations result from the errors and inaccuracies which tend to arise during hand-copying, especially over long periods of time. For example, if a [[scribe]] made an error when copying a text and omitted some lines, he would have tended to include the omitted material in the margin. However, margin notes made by readers are present in almost all manuscripts. Therefore, a different scribe seeking to produce a copy of the manuscript perhaps many years later could find it very difficult to determine whether a margin note was an omission made by the previous scribe (which should be included in the text) or simply a note made by a reader (which should be ignored or kept in the margin).
Conscientious scribes tended to copy everything which appeared in a manuscript, but in all cases scribes needed to exercise personal judgement. Explanatory notes would tend to find their way into the body of a text as a natural result of this subjective process.
Modern scholars have developed techniques{{Which|date=August 2010}} for recognizing interpolation, which are often apparent to modern observers, but would have been less so for medieval copyists.
The [[Comma Johanneum]], for example, is commonly regarded as interpolation. The specific problem of Christian transmission of Jewish texts outside the Jewish and Christian canons is often described as [[Christian interpolation]].

{{pp-vandalism|expiry=10:28, 7 May 2019|small=yes}} {{Infobox person |name=Joseph Nicolosi |image = Joseph_Nicolosi.jpg |birth_date={{birth date|1947|01|24}} | birth_place = New York |death_date = {{death date and age|2017|3|8|1947|01|24}}Sandomir, Richard (March 16, 2017). [https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/16/us/joseph-nicolosi-dead-gay-conversion-therapist.html?_r=0 "Joseph Nicolosi, Advocate of Conversion Therapy for Gays, Dies at 70"]. ''The New York Times''. |spouse = {{marriage|Linda Nicolosi|1978|2017}}{{cite web |title= Post number 652660888270320 |url= https://www.facebook.com/drjosephnicolosi/posts/652660888270320 |author= Joseph Nicolosi: Thomas Aquinas Psychological Clinic |date= March 9, 2017 |accessdate= March 11, 2017 |quote= Linda Nicolosi, Joe's lifelong collaborator and also his wife of 39 years, is grateful for everyone's prayers ... |work= [[Facebook]] }} |death_place = [[California]], U.S. |occupation=[[Psychologist]] }} '''Joseph Nicolosi''' (January 24, 1947 – March 8, 2017) was an American clinical [[psychologist]], founder and director of the Thomas Aquinas Psychological Clinic in [[Encino, California]], and a founder and president of the [[National Association for Research & Therapy of Homosexuality|National Association for Research and Therapy of Homosexuality]] (NARTH). Nicolosi advocated and practiced [[Conversion therapy#Reparative therapy|reparative therapy]], a [[pseudoscience|pseudoscientific]] and controversial practice that he claimed could help people overcome or mitigate their homosexual desires and replace them with heterosexual ones. == Biography == Nicolosi described his theories in ''Reparative Therapy of Male Homosexuality: A New Clinical Approach'' (1991) and three other books. Nicolosi proposed that [[homosexuality]] is often the product of a condition he described as gender-identity deficit caused by an alienation from, and perceived rejection by, individuals of the subject's gender.Joseph Nicolosi, Ph.D., ''Reparative Therapy of Male Homosexuality'', Rowman & Littlefield, 2004, {{ISBN|0-7657-0142-1}} Like all forms of [[conversion therapy]], reparative therapy is [[pseudoscience|pseudoscientific]], based on faulty assumptions, opposed by mainstream medical and psychological practitioners, and potentially harmful to patients.{{cite journal|last = Haldeman|first = Douglas C.|year = 1999|title = The Pseudo-science of Sexual Orientation Conversion Therapy|volume = 4|issue = 1|journal = Angles: The Policy Journal of the Institute for Gay and Lesbian Strategic Studies|url = http://drdoughaldeman.com/doc/Pseudo-Science.pdf|quote = [T]he term "reparative therapy" ... inaccurately implies "broken-ness" as the distinctive feature of homosexuality and bisexuality. ... Since mainstream mental health organizations have rejected this position, the more accurate term for therapeutic efforts to change homosexual orientation is sexual orientation conversion therapy, or simply, conversion therapy. ... Theorists such as Nicolosi and Socarides maintain that homosexuals suffer from an arrest of normal development ... [but their theories] have never been empirically validated. ... [R]eviews show that no study claiming success for conversion therapy meets the research standards that would support such a claim. ... Conversion therapy is not just an individual mental health issue but has implications for society. This discredited and ineffective psychological treatment harms people and reinforces the notion that homosexuality is bad. In this regard, it is not a compassionate effort to help homosexuals in pain, but a means of exploiting unhappy people and of reinforcing social hostility to homosexuality. Herein lies the real "reparative therapy:" helping refugees of conversion therapy reconstruct their sense of identity and rediscover their capacity to love, as well as repairing a society still affected by the myth that lesbian, gay, and bisexual people are mentally ill. Reparative efforts are best directed toward a broken social context, not the individual who has been victimized by it.}}{{cite journal|last = Ford|first = Jeffry G.|year = 2001|title = Healing homosexuals: A psychologist's journey through the ex-gay movement and the pseudo-science of reparative therapy|journal = [[Journal of Gay & Lesbian Psychotherapy]]|volume = 5|issue = 3–4|pages = 69–86|doi = 10.1300/J236v05n03_06}}{{cite web|author = [[Australian Psychological Society]]|year = 2015|title = APS Position Statement on the use of psychological practices that attempt to change sexual orientation|website = psychology.org.au|publisher = [[Australian Psychological Society]]|url = https://www.psychology.org.au/getmedia/95cfcca4-009c-4a75-a0e7-597d68e5a55c/Position_statement_on_psychological_practices_that_attempt_to_change_sexual_orientation_members.pdf|accessdate = March 17, 2018|deadurl = no|archive-date = March 17, 2018|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20180317021307/https://www.psychology.org.au/getmedia/95cfcca4-009c-4a75-a0e7-597d68e5a55c/Position_statement_on_psychological_practices_that_attempt_to_change_sexual_orientation_members.pdf|quote = [S]ome organisations and individuals practicing outside the remit of professional bodies such as the American Psychiatric Association or the Australian Psychological Society continue to advocate for therapeutic approaches that treat homosexuality and bisexuality as disorders. These are most commonly referred to as ‘reparative’ or ‘conversion’ therapies. Many such approaches are guided by particular interpretations of religious texts ...
'''The APS strongly opposes any approach to psychological practice or research that treats lesbians, gay men, and bisexual people as disordered. The APS also strongly opposes any approach to psychological practice or research that attempts to change an individual’s sexual orientation.''' ...
[T]he Code of Ethics [of the Society] states: "psychologists avoid discriminating unfairly against people on the basis of age, religion, sexuality, ethnicity, gender, disability, or any other basis proscribed by law” [and that] "in the course of their conduct, psychologists: a) communicate respect for other people through their actions and language, b) do not behave in a manner that, having regard to the context, may reasonably be perceived as coercive or demeaning, and c) respect the legal rights and moral rights of others". It should be noted, however, that this requirement not to discriminate and to respect clients’ moral rights does not equate to a justification to treat homosexuality or bisexuality as a disorder requiring treatment [as the Code also states that] "psychologists only provide psychological services within the boundaries of their professional competence. This includes but is not restricted to... b) basing their service on established knowledge of the discipline and profession of psychology".
'''There is no peer-reviewed empirical psychological research objectively documenting the ability to ‘change’ an individual’s sexual orientation. Furthermore, there is no peer-reviewed empirical psychological research demonstrating that homosexuality or bisexuality constitutes a disorder.''' ...
Psychologists are responsible for the professional decisions they make and may be liable to investigation for professional misconduct in the event a client makes a claim of maleficence. It is, of course, appropriate for psychologists to provide clinical services to clients who experience distress in regards to their sexual orientation. It is also appropriate for psychological research to be undertaken on this topic. However, the Australian Psychological Society advises that such practice and research should seek to understand ''the reasons for'' distress and how it may be alleviated. Evidence-based strategies to alleviate distress do not include attempts at changing sexual orientation, but could include challenging negative stereotypes, seeking social support, and self-acceptance, among others. (emphases in original)}} He held a [[Ph.D.]] from the [[California School of Professional Psychology]]. Nicolosi was a founding member of the [[National Association for Research & Therapy of Homosexuality]] (NARTH) and was its president for some time. NARTH is a professional association that promotes the acceptance of [[conversion therapy]]. He was an advisor to, and officer of, NARTH.{{cite web|url=http://www.narth.com/menus/officers.html |title=NARTH Officers |accessdate=2010-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040803174911/http://www.narth.com/menus/officers.html |archivedate=2004-08-03 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.narth.com/menus/advisors.html |title=NARTH Advisors |accessdate=2010-05-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080617025223/http://www.narth.com/menus/advisors.html |archivedate=2008-06-17 |df= }} In 2012, California passed a law that [[List of U.S. jurisdictions banning conversion therapy for minors|banned the provision of conversion therapy to minors]], including some of Nicolosi's existing patients. Nicolosi was named as a plaintiff in a [[Pickup v. Brown and Welch v. Brown|lawsuit challenging the law on constitutional grounds]]{{cite news|title=Second Lawsuit Filed against Calif. Gay Therapy Ban|url=http://www.cbn.com/cbnnews/us/2012/October/Second-Lawsuit-Filed-against-Calif-Gay-Therapy-Ba/|accessdate=23 August 2015|agency=CBN|date=October 7, 2012}} but the law, effectively barring Nicolosi's clinic from taking on patients under the age of 18, was subsequently upheld. The Supreme Court later explicitly referenced this case.https://www.supremecourt.gov/opinions/17pdf/16-1140_5368.pdf He died in March 2017 at the age of 70 from complications from the flu.Allen, Samantha (March 9, 2017). [http://www.thedailybeast.com/cheats/2017/03/09/ex-gay-therapy-leader-joseph-nicolosi-dead-at-70.html "'Ex-Gay Therapy' Leader Dead at 70"]. ''[[The Daily Beast]]''. == See also == * [[Sexual orientation]] * [[Sexual orientation change efforts]] ==Publications== *Nicolosi, Joseph (1991). ''Reparative Therapy of Male Homosexuality: A New Clinical Approach''. Jason Aronson, Inc. {{ISBN|0-87668-545-9}}. *Nicolosi, Joseph (1993). ''Healing Homosexuality: Case Stories of Reparative Therapy''. Jason Aronson, Inc. {{ISBN|0-7657-0144-8}}. *{{cite journal |last=Nicolosi |first=Joseph |title=Retrospective self-reports of changes in homosexual orientation: A consumer survey of conversion therapy clients |author2=Byrd, A. Dean |author3=Potts, Richard W. |url=http://doi.apa.org/index.cfm?fuseaction=showUIDAbstract&uid=2000-00515-002 |publisher=Psychological Reports |date=June 2000 |volume=86 |pages=1071–1088}} *{{cite journal |year = 2002 |last = Nicolosi |first = Joseph |title = A meta-analytic review of treatment of homosexuality. |publisher = Psychological Reports |url = http://www.biomedexperts.com/Abstract.bme/12150399/A_meta-analytic_review_of_treatment_of_homosexuality |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716215651/http://www.biomedexperts.com/Abstract.bme/12150399/A_meta-analytic_review_of_treatment_of_homosexuality |archivedate = 2011-07-16 |df = }} *Nicolosi, Joseph & Nicolosi, Linda Ames (2002). ''A Parent's Guide to Preventing Homosexuality''. InterVarsity Press. {{ISBN|0-8308-2379-4}}. *{{cite journal |year = 2002 |last = Nicolosi |first = Joseph |title = A critique of Bem's "exotic becomes erotic" theory of sexual orientation development. |publisher = Psychological Reports |url = http://www.biomedexperts.com/Abstract.bme/12150399/A_meta-analytic_review_of_treatment_of_homosexuality |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716215651/http://www.biomedexperts.com/Abstract.bme/12150399/A_meta-analytic_review_of_treatment_of_homosexuality |archivedate = 2011-07-16 |df = }} *{{cite journal |year = 2008 |last = Nicolosi |first = Joseph |title = Clients' perceptions of how reorientation therapy and self-help can promote changes in sexual orientation. |publisher = Psychological Reports |url = http://www.biomedexperts.com/Abstract.bme/18481660/Clients_perceptions_of_how_reorientation_therapy_and_self-help_can_promote_changes_in_sexual_orientation |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716215656/http://www.biomedexperts.com/Abstract.bme/18481660/Clients_perceptions_of_how_reorientation_therapy_and_self-help_can_promote_changes_in_sexual_orientation |archivedate = 2011-07-16 |df = }} *Nicolosi, Joseph (2009). ''Shame and Attachment Loss: The Practical Work of Reparative Therapy''. InterVarsity Press *Nicolosi, Joseph (2017). ''A Parent's Guide to Preventing Homosexuality'', revised edition. Liberal Mind Publishers == References == {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.josephnicolosi.com/}} *[https://archive.is/20130129114141/http://www.narth.com/docs/preventing.html Author interview: ''A Parent's Guide to Preventing Homosexuality''] by Dr. Joseph Nicolosi and Linda Nicolosi. *[https://archive.is/20130104081802/http://www.narth.com/docs/repair.html Book Excerpt: ''Reparative Therapy of Male Homosexuality''] by Dr. Joseph Nicolosi. *[https://archive.is/20130104050105/http://www.narth.com/docs/cases.html Book excerpt: ''Healing Homosexuality: Case Stories of Reparative Therapy''] by Dr. Joseph Nicolosi. *[https://archive.is/20130129200553/http://www.narth.com/docs/excerpt.html Book excerpt: ''A Parent's Guide to Preventing Homosexuality''] by Dr. Joseph Nicolosi and Linda Nicolosi. *[https://www.jstor.org/discover/10.2307/3812731?uid=3738776&uid=2129&uid=2&uid=70&uid=4&sid=21101432891121 Review: ''Therapy Terminable and Interminable: 'Non-gay Homosexuals' Come Out of the Closet''] by [[James Weinrich]]. A scholarly review of one of Nicolosi's scholarly books about conversion therapy. {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Nicolosi, Joseph}} [[Category:1947 births]] [[Category:2017 deaths]] [[Category:American psychologists]] [[Category:American Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Conversion therapy]] [[Category:Ex-gay movement]] [[Category:Sexual orientation change efforts]] [[Category:Sexual orientation and medicine]] [[Category:Deaths from influenza]]

'''Lack of [[physical education]]''' is the inadequacy of the provision and effectiveness of [[exercise]] and physical activity within modern [[education]].<ref>{{citation |title=The disappearance of physical education |author=Shannon W. Weed |year=2005 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SaSDHAAACAAJ}}</ref>
When physical education fails to meet its goals of providing students with the knowledge base, life [[habit]]s, and [[mindset]] necessary to be physically [[Physical activity level|active]] throughout their lifetime,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sallis|first=James F|year=2012|title=Physical Education's Role in Public Health: Steps Forward and Backward Over 20 Years and HOPE for the Future|url=|journal=Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> it can lead children to adopt a [[sedentary lifestyle]]. According to a 2010 study by the [[World Health Organization|WHO]], 81% of children aged 11–17 worldwide did not meet the minimum recommended [[Physical exercise|exercise]] guidelines of 60 minutes daily.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.who.int/gho/ncd/risk_factors/physical_activity_text/en/|title=WHO {{!}} Prevalence of insufficient physical activity|website=www.who.int|access-date=2016-11-23}}</ref> [[File:Physical education class.jpg|thumb|A physical education class for secondary students in Havana, Cuba.]] Although more prevalent in countries of [[high income]],<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hallal|first=Pedro C|last2=Andersen|first2=Lars Bo|last3=Bull|first3=Fiona C|last4=Guthold|first4=Regina|last5=Haskell|first5=William|last6=Ekelund|first6=Ulf|title=Global physical activity levels: surveillance progress, pitfalls, and prospects|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0140673612606461|journal=The Lancet|volume=380|issue=9838|pages=247–257|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(12)60646-1}}</ref> physical inactivity is an [[international]] issue that is correlated with an [[obesity]] epidemic<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://med.stanford.edu/news/all-news/2014/07/lack-of-exercise--not-diet--linked-to-rise-in-obesity--stanford-.html|title=Lack of exercise, not diet, linked to rise in obesity, Stanford research shows|website=News Center|access-date=2016-11-22}}</ref> and negative physical,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lee|first=I-Min|last2=Shiroma|first2=Eric J|last3=Lobelo|first3=Felipe|last4=Puska|first4=Pekka|last5=Blair|first5=Steven N|last6=Katzmarzyk|first6=Peter T|title=Effect of physical inactivity on major non-communicable diseases worldwide: an analysis of burden of disease and life expectancy|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(12)61031-9|journal=The Lancet|volume=380|issue=9838|pages=219–229|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(12)61031-9}}</ref> psychological,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ploughman|first=Michelle|date=2008-01-01|title=Exercise is brain food: The effects of physical activity on cognitive function|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/17518420801997007|journal=Developmental Neurorehabilitation|volume=11|issue=3|pages=236–240|doi=10.1080/17518420801997007|issn=1751-8423|pmid=18781504}}</ref> and [[Academia|academic]] consequences <ref>{{Cite journal|last=Rasberry|first=Catherine N.|last2=Lee|first2=Sarah M.|last3=Robin|first3=Leah|last4=Laris|first4=B.A.|last5=Russell|first5=Lisa A.|last6=Coyle|first6=Karin K.|last7=Nihiser|first7=Allison J.|title=The association between school-based physical activity, including physical education, and academic performance: A systematic review of the literature|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0091743511000557|journal=Preventive Medicine|volume=52|pages=S10–S20|doi=10.1016/j.ypmed.2011.01.027}}</ref> in children.
A high quality physical education programs consists of these attributes:<ref name=":7">{{Cite web|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK201493/|title=Committee on Physical Activity and Physical Education in the School Environment|last=|first=|date=2013|website=National Academy of Sciences|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
* Physical education teachers are certified * Students in elementary school have physical education class for a minimum of 150 minutes per week, while students in high school have it for at least 225 minutes per week * Concrete and achievable standards for students to meet (often for high school graduation)
[[File:Coach Stacey and PE Parachute.jpg|thumb|Elementary students playing with a parachute in their physical education class in Leland, North Carolina, USA.]]
==Causes== The causes of lack of physical education vary from country to country. These include a shortage in facilities and [[Sports equipment|equipment]], a paucity of [[Gym teacher|physical education teachers]], large [[Student–teacher ratio|class sizes]], and budgetary constraints.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> In some African countries such as [[Botswana]] and [[Malawi]], where children attend school for a minimal amount of time, the budgets allocated for physical education are instead used to concentrate on subjects such as [[language]]s and [[mathematics]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
A lack of physical education also arises from cultural views: in parts of [[Central America]] (such as the [[The Bahamas|Bahamas]]) and [[Asia]] (such as [[Pakistan]]), exercise is seen as a form of leisure that should not be featured in an academic [[curriculum]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> Another example exists in [[India]], where girls are often discouraged from engaging in [[sport]]s because such activity is viewed as "unfeminine", as is the possibility of them becoming too muscular.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Moreover, a lack of governmental [[legislation]] and intervention can be to blame. In parts of [[South America]] (with the exception of [[Chile]] and [[Colombia]]), there are no laws that make physical education compulsory: thus, it is omitted from many schools.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.icsspe.org/content/physical-education-schools-update|title=Physical Education in Schools Update {{!}} International Council of Sport Science and Physical Education|website=www.icsspe.org|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
In other cases, such as in areas of the [[United States]], the mandated physical education hours are simply not met.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/11/education/even-as-schools-battle-obesity-physical-education-is-sidelined.html|title=Even as Obesity Concerns Rise, Physical Education Is Sidelined|last=Baker|first=Al|date=2012-07-10|newspaper=The New York Times|issn=0362-4331|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> For example, in 33 states, students are permitted to be exempt from physical education courses by replacing them with other activities such as marching band practices.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/11/14/2012-shape-of-the-nation-_n_2130115.html|title=Physical Education Programs Stalled By State Loopholes: 2012 Shape Of The Nation Report|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|via=}}</ref>
Outside of school, children often fail to engage in physical activity due to lack of [[physical literacy]], inadequate [[Sleep deprivation|sleep]], the increasing attractiveness of rival pastimes such as [[video game]]s, and parents that do not play their part. It is important that parents allow their children the full opportunity to participate in both formal and informal sports and promote healthy physical activity levels. Also, in achievement-oriented populations such as those seen in [[China]], there is an increased emphasis on [[Test (assessment)|academic results]] which also detracts from physical activity time.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.boston.com/news/local/massachusetts/articles/2007/05/30/lack_of_physical_education_weighs_heavily_on_many/ |title=Lack of physical education weighs heavily on many |publisher=The Boston Globe |author=Lisa Wangsness |author2= April Simpson |date=May 30, 2007}}</ref>
The deterioration of physical education in schools combined with the elimination of playgrounds and other play facilities forces children to stay inactive and inside for most of the school day which can have serious long-term consequences.<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Weiler|first=Richard|date=2014|title=Is the Lack of Physical Activity Strategy for Children Complicit Mass Child Neglect?|url=|journal=British Journal of Sports Medicine|volume=48|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Consequences == [[File:Medical complications of obesity.png|thumb|Physical consequences of obesity]] An increase in [[sedentary lifestyle]] due to a lack of physical education at home and at school has many physical and psychological consequences on a child in the short and long term.
=== Physical === According to a Portuguese study, children with sedentary lifestyles have nine times poorer [[motor coordination]] than active children of the same age.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lopes|first=Luís|last2=Santos|first2=Rute|last3=Pereira|first3=Beatriz|last4=Lopes|first4=Vítor Pires|date=2012-11-01|title=Associations between sedentary behavior and motor coordination in children|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajhb.22310/abstract|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|language=en|volume=24|issue=6|pages=746–752|doi=10.1002/ajhb.22310|issn=1520-6300}}</ref> They also have worsened [[bone density]], [[Physical strength|strength]], and [[Flexibility (anatomy)|flexibility]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://healthycanadians.gc.ca/healthy-living-vie-saine/being-active-etre-actif/tips-conseils-eng.php|title=Children and physical activity|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> In the long term, they are more likely to use [[tobacco]], [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]], and [[drug]]s than their active peers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://healthycanadians.gc.ca/healthy-living-vie-saine/being-active-etre-actif/tips-conseils-eng.php|title=Children and physical activity|last=Canada|first=Government of Canada, Health Canada and the Public health Agency of|website=healthycanadians.gc.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Sedentary behaviour is strongly associated with [[obesity]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.statcan.gc.ca/pub/82-003-x/2011001/article/11397-eng.htm|title=Physical activity of Canadian children and youth: Accelerometer results from the 2007 to 2009 Canadian Health Measures Survey|website=www.statcan.gc.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> and this imparts a great health risk. Obese children are more likely to have [[Hypertension|high blood pressure]], [[Cardiovascular disease|heart disease]], high [[Low-density lipoprotein|LDL cholesterol]], [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|Type 2 diabetes mellitus]], [[sleep apnea]], [[menstrual cycle]] abnormalities, [[bone]] and [[joint]] problems, increased [[cancer]] risk, and reduced balance.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://health.ucsd.edu/specialties/surgery/bariatric/weight-loss-surgery/adolescent-weight-loss/Pages/health-risks.aspx|title=Health Risks of Childhood Obesity - Bariatric and Metabolic Institute {{!}} UC San Diego Health|website=UC Health - UC San Diego|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> They are also more likely to be obese adults.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthyschools/obesity/facts.htm|title=Obesity Prevention {{!}} Healthy Schools {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Childhood physical inactivity has been correlated to cholesterol and fatty streaks in the aorta in the first decade of life and moves to the heart, brain, and other parts of the body in the second and third decade of life, causing health issues.<ref name=":8" />
A lack of physical activity is one of the main causes for obesity, cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and other physical health issues among children and adolescents.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Guedes|first=Claudia|date=2007|title=Physical Education and Physical Activity: A Historical Perspective|url=|journal=Journal of Physical Education, Recreation & Dance|volume=78|pages=31-48|via=}}</ref>
There is a direct correlation between active participation in physical activity and the health of school age children, therefore a lack of physical education would cause a lack in physical activity in children, leading to worse health.<ref name=":7" />
=== Psychological === As exercise is known to improve well-being and reduce [[Stress (biology)|stress]], physical inactivity is correlated with poor psychological health<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Goodwin|first=Donna L|year=1996|title=Cut-backs to physical education consulting services: consequences and concerns.|url=|journal=CAHPER Journal|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> such as an increase of major [[Depression (mood)|depression]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Win|first=Sithu|last2=Parakh|first2=Kapil|last3=Eze-Nliam|first3=Chete M.|last4=Gottdiener|first4=John S.|last5=Kop|first5=Willem J.|last6=Ziegelstein|first6=Roy C.|date=2011-03-15|title=Depressive symptoms, physical inactivity and risk of cardiovascular mortality in older adults: the Cardiovascular Health Study|url=http://heart.bmj.com/content/97/6/500|journal=Heart|language=en|volume=97|issue=6|pages=500–505|doi=10.1136/hrt.2010.209767|issn=1468-201X|pmc=3044493|pmid=21339320}}</ref> There is a link between obesity and psychiatric illness and the two feed on each other in a vicious cycle.
A lack of physical activity is associated with poorer [[Concentration (psychology)|concentration]] and [[Academic achievement|academic performance]], particularly in [[mathematics]] and [[Reading (process)|reading]].<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK201501/|title=Physical Activity, Fitness, and Physical Education: Effects on Academic Performance|last=Harold W. Kohl|first=I. I. I.|last2=Cook|first2=Heather D.|last3=Environment|first3=Committee on Physical Activity and Physical Education in the School|last4=Board|first4=Food and Nutrition|last5=Medicine|first5=Institute of|date=2013-10-30|publisher=National Academies Press (US)|language=en}}</ref>
Obesity induced from lack of exercise also contributes to a decrease in general mental health. Overweight children and teens are more likely to suffer from poor [[self-esteem]], negative [[body image]], [[teasing]], and [[bullying]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.cdc.gov/healthyschools/obesity/facts.htm|title=Obesity Prevention {{!}} Healthy Schools {{!}} CDC|website=www.cdc.gov|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Higher levels of sedentary and lower levels of physical education are linked to worse mental health and lower cognitive function among children.<ref name=":8" />
== In Canada ==
=== Current trends === The majority of Canadian children aged 5 to 17 years old (91%) do not meet the daily physical activity recommendations.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> Although Canadian physical education programs are improving significantly, with 61-80% of schools offering a minimum of 150 minutes of physical education classes per week in 2016, and participation levels in [[organized sport]] are on the rise, Canadian school programs are ineffective in encouraging healthy habits.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> In fact, most Canadian children (56%) lack physical literacy.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref> Consequently, they face many issues related to lifestyle. These include sedentary behaviours such as increased screen time averaging 176 minutes a day from TVs and video games to the detriment of active play. There is also the inevitable decrease in [[Human-powered transport|active transportation]], more [[sleep deprivation]], and a poor quality of [[Dieting|diet]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.participaction.com/en-ca/thought-leadership/report-card/2016|title=Are Canadian Kids Too Tired to Move? {{!}} ParticipACTION|website=ParticipACTION|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
These lifestyle trends have caused youth obesity rates to nearly triple over the past 30 years. In 2013, this consisted of 28% of Canadian children ages 5–19 that were classified as [[overweight]] or [[Obesity|obese]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://childhoodobesityfoundation.ca/about/|title=About - Childhood Obesity Foundation|newspaper=Childhood Obesity Foundation|access-date=2016-11-24|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
==== Recommendations and Regulations ==== The Canadian Association for Health, Physical Education, Recreation and Dance (CAHPERD) has recommended that Canadian schools and [[Board of education|school boards]] take action through specific academic initiatives to ensuring that their physical education [[curriculum]] is effective at encouraging and instilling healthy exercise habits in young Canadians. CAHPERD has suggested that schools focus on checking the quality (adequate facilities, budget and research-verified techniques) and quantity (minimum 30 minutes a day) of a school's physical education courses as well as the professional qualifications of the educators. The consultants should check that classes meet the needs of all students irrespective of [[Race (human categorization)|race]], [[sex]], [[gender]], and [[Agility|ability level]]. The courses should also encourage participation and [[skill]] development, with a healthy balance of [[Competitiveness|competitive]] and noncompetitive activities. Moreover, it is of utmost importance that [[Physical exercise|physical activity]] and [[physical education]] be encouraged by the [[teacher]]: they should never be used to [[Punishment|punish]] a student (such as what is seen through the common practice of making children run if they misbehave). Outside of class hours, CAHPERD recommends that schools provide opportunities for [[Intramural sports|intramural]] activities and involve [[parent]]s in the [[Fitness (biology)|fitness]] initiative.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phecanada.ca/advocacy/advocacy-tools/making-case-physical-education-canada-presentation-kit-leaders|title=Making the Case for Physical Education in Canada: A Presentation Kit for Leaders {{!}} PHE Canada|date=2010-07-23|website=www.phecanada.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The Pan-Canadian Public Health Network first decided to prioritize the issue of childhood obesity in September 2010 by creating the framework ''Curbing Childhood Obesity: An overview of the Federal, Provincial and Territorial Framework for Action to Promote Healthy Weights.'' In this project, federal, provincial and territorial Ministers of Health agreed to focus on three goals: increasing the predominance of [[Nutrition|nutritious]] food choices, addressing obesity at an early age, and creating better spaces for children that favour physical activity and [[Healthy diet|healthy eating]]. This has allowed the [[action plan]] ''Towards a Healthier Canada'' to be created.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/hp-ps/hl-mvs/framework-cadre/intro-eng.php|title=Curbing Childhood Obesity: An Overview of the FPT Framework for Action to Promote Healthy Weights - Public Health Agency of Canada|last=Canada|first=Government of Canada, Public Health Agency of|website=www.phac-aspc.gc.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The Canadian Physical Activity guidelines for children ages 5 to 17 consist of at least 1 hour of daily physical activity. Their exercise should range in intensity from [[Moderate exercise|moderate]] (inducing light [[perspiration]] and harder [[breathing]]) to vigorous (inducing heavy perspiration and heavy breathing). Examples of moderate exercise include [[Bicycle|bike]] riding and [[playground]] activities, and examples of vigorous exercise include [[running]] and [[Swimming (sport)|swimming.]] It is recommended that they engage in both vigorous activities and activities strengthening bone and muscles at least three times a week.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csep.ca/en/guidelines/24-hour-movement-guidelines|title=Guidelines|website=www.csep.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The Canadian Society for Exercise Physiology also recommends that children ages 5 to 17 limit their sedentary activities, such as [[television]] and video games, [[Transport|sedentary transport]], and extensive [[sitting]]. It is advised that children limit their recreational screen time to a maximum of 120 minutes a day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.csep.ca/en/guidelines/24-hour-movement-guidelines|title=Guidelines|website=www.csep.ca|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
The ''[[Childhood Obesity]] Foundation'', a Canadian initiative, has invented the 5-2-1-0 [[mnemonic]] to remember the national lifestyle recommendations. This consists of 5 [[Serving size|servings]] or more of [[vegetable]]s and [[fruit]] per day, no more than 2 hours of screen time a day, 1 hour of [[Physical exercise|physical activity]] or more per day, and 0 [[sugary drink]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://childhoodobesityfoundation.ca/about/|title=About - Childhood Obesity Foundation|newspaper=Childhood Obesity Foundation|language=en-US|access-date=2016-11-24}}</ref>
Since the inception of ''Towards a Healthier Canada'', many initiatives have been launched to meet the three goals, and they vary from [[Provinces and territories of Canada|province]] to province.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.phn-rsp.ca/thcpr-vcpsre-2015/index-eng.php|title=Towards a Healthier Canada : Compilation of Initiatives|last=|first=|date=|website=towardsahealthiercanada.ca|publisher=|access-date=}}</ref> They are projects made in the name of a framework or jurisdictional approach/governmental department that are either targeted at schools, at a community, or in partnership with other organizations or companies.
== In the United States ==
=== Current Trends === Nearly 10 million [[Child|children]] and [[Adolescence|adolescents]] in the United States ages 6–19 are considered [[overweight]] because the lack of physical education in schools. <ref>{{citation|title=Physical Education in Schools|url=http://www.americanheart.org/presenter.jhtml?identifier=3010854}}</ref> Children aged 6–11 have also more than doubled in rate of [[obesity]] over the last twenty years. <ref>{{citation|author=Leslie Haub|title=Childhood obesity and the lack of physical education programs|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eGNXNAAACAAJ|year=2007}}</ref>
Individual states have set requirements for physical education in their schools, but how physical education is conducted across the country has not been established. Yet, physical education has been a common practice of the K-12 education curriculum in the United States.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=McKenzie|first=Thomas|date=2017|title=Studies of Physical Education in the United States Using SOFIT: A Review|url=|journal=Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport|volume=88|pages=492-502|via=}}</ref>
The No Child Left Behind Act has created an environment in which physical education, art and music have been left behind, viewed as "nonessential" courses. Federal funding is more dependent on schools enhancing their math and reading programs.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Sallis|first=James|date=2012|title=Physical Education's Role in Public Health|url=|journal=Research Quarterly for Exercise and Sport|volume=83|pages=125-135|via=}}</ref>
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
===== Regulations and Recommendations ===== One program the United States has adopted to decrease obesity are before-school exercise programs with elementary aged children. One in particular consists of reaching 100 miles before the end of the school year. Each milestone of 25 miles the child will earn a check mark on a tee-shirt. They will then be rewarded at 100 miles with a trophy and an announcement over the school loudspeaker. Walking is supervised by teachers and done around school grounds or inside the school. This is a great way for a child to improve health, concentration, confidence and happiness.
Throughout the past two decades, federal support for physical education in the public health sector has increased dramatically. Since 1992, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has funded state education agencies to get them to partner with state health departments to promote physical activity and healthy eating in schools among young people. <ref name=":1" />
In February 2010, first lady Michelle Obama started the "Let's Move" initiative to address the childhood obesity epidemic. Efforts to engage in schools to fight against childhood obesity were taken within 1 year of establishing the program.<ref name=":1" />
Budget cuts in the United States have led to less funding and support for physical education because it is not a "core" subject.<ref name=":1" />
== In China ==
=== Current Trends === Even though obesity has increased among most of the population in China, the burden of obesity has shifted onto the lower educated population, likely due to a lack of physical education or health education.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Wang|first=Huijun|date=2013|title=Program and Policy Options for Preventing Obesity in China|url=|journal=National Center for Biotechnology Information|volume=14|pages=134-140|via=}}</ref>
Students in China are beginning to gain equal opportunities to physical education and sports to further improve their physical health and strength.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Tsai|first=Chiung-Tzu Lucetta|date=2017|title=The History of Sports and Physical Education in China|url=|journal=World Leisure Journal|volume=59|pages=326-337|via=}}</ref>
Sport and physical education in China is extremely influenced by Confucianism which emphasizes collectivism. The values it holds emphasizes self-sacrifice and subordination of one's interests to those of others.<ref name=":2" />
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
===== Regulations and Recommendations ===== In 2011, The Chinese Ministry of Education has developed standards for physical education in schools. These emphasize enhancing children's health development is the primary goal of physical education in schools.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Ding|first=Haiyong|date=2014|title=A Review of Scholarly and Research Work in Physical Education in China During the First Decade of the 21st Century|url=|journal=Quest|volume=66|pages=117-133|via=}}</ref> These standards include:
* "Standard 1: Physical activity participation—Students participate in physical activities and are able to enjoy exercise and experience success."<ref name=":3" />
* "Standard 2: Mastery of knowledge, skill, and safe exercise methods—Students learn knowledge about exercise, perform physical skills, understand safe exercise principles, and learn self-defense."<ref name=":3" />
* "Standard 3: Developing physical health—Students learn and master knowledge and method of maintaining health, develop and sustain healthy posture and bodily shape, develop and maintain physical fitness, and improve adaptive ability in natural environments."<ref name=":3" />
* "Standard 4: Developing mental health—Students learn to develop mental strength, control emotions, develop ability to collaborate and cooperate, and follow ethical norms of physical activity."<ref name=":3" />
The General Administration of Sport in China has been one of the leading government agencies that promotes the development of physical education and physical health in the elementary and college levels.<ref name=":2" />
The government has for the most part supported physical education and sport in school, but has often abused it as a political tool which leads to ignoring its importance and the needs of individual students.<ref name=":2" />
== In European (EU) Countries ==
=== Current Trends === In the EU, physical education is a mandatory subject in general education. The time dedicated to physical education varies greatly from country to country.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=November 2016|title=Physical Education in EU Schools|url=|journal=Briefing European Parliamentary Research Service|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> About half of EU countries devote 10% of their school curriculum to physical education. Hungary, Croatia and Slovenia devote 15%, while Ireland only 4%.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Matejek|first=Črtomir|date=2014|title=Physical Education in Primary Education in EU Countries|url=|journal=Revija za Elementarno Izobraževanje|volume=7|pages=57-165|via=}}</ref>
Out of all EU countries, France devotes the most time to physical education in elementary school, a total of 108 hours, which is only 10% of the total teaching time.<ref name=":5" />
The primary education designers in European countries view physical education as less important than other subjects.<ref name=":5" />
Physical inactivity is responsible for over 500,000 deaths per year in the European Union and accounts for economic costs of over €80 billion per year.<ref name=":4" />
Funding for physical education in EU schools is poor, which has led to poor quality physical education. This lack of funding is reflected in poor quality and lack of equipment at EU schools in respectively 26% and 38% of EU countries.<ref name=":4" />
=== Addressing the Lack of Physical Education ===
===== Regulations and Recommendations ===== In 2007, the European Parliament's Resolution on the Role of Sport in Education helped parliament conclude that physical education is “the only school subject which seeks to prepare children for a healthy lifestyle and focuses on their overall physical and mental development, as well as imparting important social values such as fairness, self-discipline, solidarity, team spirit, tolerance and fair play…” and one of the most important tools for social integration.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Hardman|first=Ken|date=2008|title=Physical Education in Schools: A Global Perspective|url=|journal=University of Worcester, UK|volume=1|pages=5-28|via=}}</ref>
European Parliament's Resolution places physical education on the European political agenda, highlighting its importance.<ref name=":6" />
The European Physical Education Association recommends daily physical education in elementary grades up to 11 or 12 years of age and 3 hours per week in post-elementary and high school grades.<ref name=":6" />
